name: Girl Rising
bio: Girl Rising uses the power of storytelling to change the way the world values girls and their education.

social_posts.post_text:
We are proud of our Kenya Program Coordinator Debborah Odenyi (@deborahodenyi) who was featured on Kenya's national news KBC Channel 1 on a segment that focused on how the Girl Rising programs work to remove barriers in the way of girls' education is positively impacting remote and marginalized communities.

Debbie spoke with deep knowledge about issues like early child marriage, gender-based violence, digital inequity, and gender stereotypes which continue to prevent girls from receiving the education that they are legally required to get in Kenya. The Girl Rising program helps girls tackle some of these issues to help bridge gaps in their education access. Click on the link in our bio to watch her whole interview.

Like many around the world, 14-year-old Mackrine's father lost his job as a porter at the start of the pandemic in Kibera, Kenya, meaning her parents were at risk of not being able to afford to send her to school. However, Mackrine was inspired by the story of Wadley from the original Girl Rising films and felt equipped by the self-confidence she had acquired from Girl Rising programming and she decided to march into the School Managing Director's office and self-advocate to be allowed to stay in school without temporarily paying the school fees.

Mackrine's Girl Rising mentors and facilitators were amazed to see the confidence of the girl who entered the program as a shy and timid young child. Mackrine is an example of how socio-emotional learning and mentorship provided by the Girl Rising programs gives girls like Mackrine the resources core socio-emotional skills to advocate for themselves and weather through unexpected barriers like the pandemic.

Mackrine is currently is Class 8 and is prepping to excel in her upcoming in her National Examinations to transition to high school. Mackrine is determined to pursue her education and aspires to become one of the top lawyers in the world. With her legal skills, she hopes to fight for justice for the oppressed and assist children and families that are disadvantaged.

Around 85 K'iche' adolescent girls from five different communities from Nahualá, Sololá in Guatemala and their family members came together to celebrate the ending of yearly Girl Rising programming with a special ceremony.

The girls, ages 7-14 shared highlights from the year’s program, their life plans, and artwork. Each was awarded a diploma, along with huge congratulations for their their hard work and growth. Collaborating with our partner REDMI has given us the privilege of reaching girls who are out of school and others who have to travel extraordinary distances to attend school. Having mentors from the same territories lead sessions and visit their homes gives girls a role model, and an example of what women can do with an education.

Evidence from 25 developed and developing countries demonstrates that countries with higher representation of women leaders in government are more likely to have more stringent climate change policies. A just and sustainable world starts with inclusive decision-making process that include girls and women.

Source: UNICEF

Girl Rising and our partners in Kenya came together in Suswa town, Narok County, Kenya to recognize World AIDS Day and 16 Day of Activism to end gender-based violence, an annual international campaign led by the Center for Women’s Global Leadership.

Our event brought together more than 100 girls aged 9-15yrs, along with young adult youth champions, parents, local religious leaders, and community health volunteers to raise their voices to end the triple threat of sexual and gender-based violence, teen pregnancy, and HIV transmission.

As schools close down for the holidays, girls in Narok County are at higher risk for Female Genital Mutilation (FGM) because they have more time at home where family and community members can force them to undergo the practice. This event and the camp sessions Girl Rising provides are created to provide a culture-specific life skills curriculum to give girls the knowledge to self-advocate for their rights but also to educate the community on how to protect girls' agency and rights. It also increases access to sexual and reproductive health information for adolescents and creates safe spaces for girls at risk of FGM.

At the start of the school year in Lagos, Nigeria, Paul chose a boy and a girl to act as prefects, students with leadership responsibilities like a hall monitor. Paul recalls telling the class that, “The head boy will be the next in charge after me, and then the head girl.” Shortly after, he attended a Girl Rising session for teachers, held in partnership with 1 Million Teachers (1MT), that tackled gender bias and preconceived notions surrounding gender roles. It was an eye-opener on how teachers unknowingly train a generation of boys and girls to withhold access from girls. He realized how setting the girl prefect to be lower in the hierarchy than the boy prefect, teaches students that girls and women are not good enough to be in top leadership positions simply because of their gender.

Paul returned to his classroom and readjusted the power dynamics between the girl and boy prefects. Now he says he is more mindful of the small actions that he takes daily that could create gender bias and he educates his students, peers, and the administration on ways they could build more inclusive spaces for all students.

UNICEF reports that more than two-thirds of countries have reached gender parity in primary school enrollment but gender disparities in access to education are still prevalent in most parts of Africa, the Middle East, and South Asia. And globally, girls are still daily fighting gender bias in curriculums and classroom practices. Girl Rising works with partners like @onemillionteachers in Nigeria to educate teachers to be frontline workers against gender bias in schools. Together, we are helping equip the next generation with the knowledge needed to create a more equitable world.

Help support our efforts to train teachers, create new locally adapted educational resources, and deliver at-home learning guides. Click on the link in our bio to give today!

(Names changed to protect privacy)

The pandemic has caused a global education crisis and an estimated 11 million girls are at risk of never returning to the classroom - this is in addition to the 129 million girls who did not have access to education even before COVID19 (UNICEF). Girl Rising is committed to taking the vital steps needed to remove the barriers that stand in the way of girls' education.

Join the movement and invest in girls’ education today. Every gift during our end-of-year campaign is matched 1:1 and can make two times the impact.

Your support helps us to train teachers, create new locally adapted educational resources, and deliver at-home learning guides. Our programs in eight countries help girls develop the skills needed to succeed in school, and engage with teachers, parents, and community leaders to address the harmful gender norms that hold girls back.

Click on the link in our bio to learn more and give.

Future Rising Fellows Connie Molina (@themelanconnie) and Faebian Ceruleo (@faebian.ceruleo), Colombia, have created an inspiring and riveting graphic novel based on the real life story of a Colombian entrepreneur, activist and acid attack survivor Natalia Ponce de León, who turned her tragedy into a national movement to combat gender-based violence and perception of women. Connie and Faebian imagined Natalia's story in a fantastical augmented reality comic book using a free augmented reality app, where readers can scan the comic book to view animation, real-life stories, films, and other interactive elements pop-out of the pages.

The book follows Natalia's story after the attack as she plunges into the abyss of constant pain and depression that takes her on a journey to a spiritual kingdom inhabited by a giant snake with the power to heal or destroy. She returns from the netherworlds as the fierce Kaia to defend the vulnerable and protect the innocent who are traumatized by injustice and violence in modern Colombia. To learn more and read the comic book visit the link in our bio.

Education is a fundamental human right. Educated individuals are better equipped to learn more about their personal agency and how to self-advocate for their rights. Girl Rising is resolved to increase equitable education access for all, especially girls who face disproportionate barriers. This #HumanRightsDay we encourage you to join us in advocating for girls' right to education.

To invest in girls' education click on the link in our bio.

Future Rising Fellows Hilda Flavia Nakabuye, Uganda, Julieta Martinez, Chile, and Tia Kennedy, First Nations in Canada were featured speakers at the Right Here, Right Now Global Climate Summit hosted by @Unhumanrights and @CUBoulder at Boulder, Colorado. They each shared their personal stories of addressing the climate crisis through local solutions and empowering the voices of marginalized community members.

Hilda, Julieta, and Tia were among other prolific voices including former Irish President Mary Robinson about the need for urgent and equitable action for climate justice. Swipe to the end for a snippet of one of Hilda's speeches.

text_entities.entity: right here right now global climate summit

social_posts.post_text:
We are so proud of Girl Rising champion and 11-year-old sports journalist Pepper Persley (@pepperpersley) for being chosen as one of Adweek's 2022 Most Powerful Women in Sports. This summer alone, Pepper has hosted a Title IX panel for Nike, reported courtside for the WNBA Champion Las Vegas Aces, reported live from the MLB Little League Classic for ESPN, and tookover WNBA Seattle Storm's Instagram. She has also moderated panels with Girl Rising and served as the host of our new series On the Rise featuring game-changing girls from all around the world.

Pepper is an inspiration to young girls all over the world, especially those aspiring to break down gender barriers in sports. We congratulate Pepper and are eager to see all the incredible things she will continue to achieve. Go, Pepper!

When nearly a third of Pakistan was submerged due to floods this year, 19-year-old Hafsa Qadir,  former Girl Rising program participant, took action. She immediately volunteered with the Welfare Association for New Generation (WANG,) a Girl Rising partner organization. WANG’s only woman-volunteer, Hafsa traveled to some of the worst impacted communities, where women and girls were disproportionately affected, distributing dignity kits containing menstrual hygiene supplies, and conducting health and hygiene awareness sessions.

The floods in Pakistan killed 1,739 people, caused 3.2 trillion ($15.2 billion) in losses, and forced 20 million people from their homes. Women and girls in relief camps experience threats to personal safety, lack of access to quality menstrual management spaces and supplies, and exposure to illnesses.

Hafsa was inspired to be an active participant in social justice causes when she saw the original Girl Rising film in Grade 7.  Her interests were further cultivated by mentors as she participated in the Girl Rising program, built new leadership skills, and better understood her ability to be a changemaker. She says that Girl Rising helped her understand that girls and women have the power to solve the world’s most pressing issues.

Girl Rising is working in 8 countries, reaching 7 million adolescents to remove barriers to girls’ education and to channel the power of girls like Hafsa.

Join us today to support girls’ education with a gift to Girl Rising - and double your impact. Click on the link in our bio to read more of Hafsa’s inspiring story and give.

This holiday season give a gift that changes lives. Make an investment in girls' education in honor of your loved one and we will notify them of your very special gift.

Right now is the perfect time to give! All gifts to Girl Rising are matched up to $100K. Click on the link in our bio to learn more about in honor gifts and to give today.

Saloni Ranjan and Jeeya Thukral, teenage poets in our partner program @slamoutloud, discuss how slam poetry has helped them learn how to understand their emotions, self-advocate, and challenge gender stereotypes in their community. Through their poems, Jeeya and Saloni have artistically challenged victim blaming in sexual assault situations, and gender bias that keeps girls and women from competing in school at the same level as their male counterparts.

Click on the link in our bio to watch Saloni and Jeeya provide a no-bars-held account of life in India, the challenges teenage girls experience, and how poetry has helped them change their family and community’s views.

On Tuesday the Afghan government barred women from attending private and public universities. This latest devastating move is an ongoing Taliban-led effort to bar girls and women from education. Girl Rising condemns this violation to girls’ and women’s rights. We stand in solidarity with human rights advocates and the women of Afghanistan in demanding that world leaders and organizations take serious actions to ensure that girls’ and women’s rights are protected, including their right to education.

14-year-old Priyanka’s mother enrolled her in Girl Rising’s social-emotional learning sessions in Rajasthan, India, hoping that she would have more access to education and self-advocacy than herself.

Prior to joining the sessions, Priyanka knew she had dreams, ambitions, fears and worries, but she didn’t have the vocabulary to fully express her feelings. Learning the correct words and their meanings helped her ensure she spoke about her emotions and thoughts more knowingly. It helped her voice her opinions more confidently and advocate for herself.

Once during an interaction with Priyanka and her mother, one of the local staff members asked her mother how she felt knowing that Priyanka is learning new skills. Her mother, bashfully smiled and looked away unable to express her feelings. But Priyanka was able to step in and boldy say, "I want to make my parents proud and give my younger siblings a role model.”

Girl Rising’s programs are giving millions of girls like Priyanka the essential skills to understand their thoughts and feelings and advocate for their rights. People who know 
how to self-advocate are more likely to do well in school, work, and life. To learn more about our programs and to give to our essential work click on the link in our bio.

Girl Rising is working for a world in which all girls learn, rise, and thrive. Be a part of making that vision a reality. With the support of donors around the world, Girl Rising’s research-proven programs reached over 7 million adolescents, 200,000 educators, and 40 partner organizations. Through our Future Rising program we are supporting 23 extraordinary young changemakers who are addressing climate justice through community action and global advocacy. Click on the link in our bio to donate to Girl Rising to support girls’ education - the world’s very best investment.

Future Rising Fellow Astrid Peraza (@astridprzj) conducted a special workshop for 16 and 17-year-old girls interested in STEM  in her hometown, Puntarenas, Costa Rica, about the importance of challenging gender norms and pursuing their aspirations. The workshop provided leadership training for girls who plan to study or work in the engineering field, a historically male-dominated industry. Puntarenas is one of Costa Rica's most underserved provinces, where work options for women are limited and education opportunities for girls are non-existent after high school. Astrid herself had to leave her family at the age of 17 and move across the country to attend university. Astrid says she is lucky because her family supported her decision to get higher education but that's not the case for many girls.

Despite Costa Rica ranking number 33 in the World Economic Forum ranking for gender parity progress, Astrid says the country has a long way to go since women still only earn 85% of a man's wage. The disparity is particularly seen in the STEM industry. Astrid says that she is determined to make Costa Rica a gender-equitable country.

Astrid is currently working with Girl Rising to create a documentary on a women's cooperative in a small fishing village on the Pacific Coast of Costa Rica to illuminate the impacts of climate change on the community.

Heena works with our partner organization Ibtada (@ibtada_alwar) in Alwar, Rajasthan, as a facilitator, teaching local adolescent girls the Girl Rising social-emotional learning (SEL) curriculum. With a master's degree in social work, Heena is the most educated person in her family and believes that her true calling in life has always been helping others. She says that the SEL lessons have helped her cultivate a better sense of self-awareness and self-identity herself. She is passionate about helping girls and families learn more about their rights, advocate for themselves and positively impact communities. She has helped hundreds of girls in Alwar, a rural community with limited resources, build their voice, agency and self-advocacy skills. Heena is a powerful example of the ripple effects across a community when one girl is given access to education. She becomes a woman who transforms lives.

We are proud to partner with strong educators and facilitators like Heena across the world who are breaking down harmful social norms and helping rebuild a more equitable world where everyone can reach their full potential. Click on the link in our bio to learn more about our programs and see how you can support.

Investing in girls’ education has a massive return on investment. Every $1 spent on girls’ rights and education generates a $2.80 value - equivalent to billions of dollars in extra Gross Domestic Product for the world. When more girls are educated there are ripple effect of positive change that benefits all of us. 

Act today to support girls’ education with a gift to Girl Rising. Right now, your donation is doubled by a very generous matching gift. Click on the link in our bio to learn more and give. 

Source: Plan International

On their way to visit a local school, our partners at the Drawing Dreams Initiative (@drawingdreams_initiative) ran into two girls - Meshami and Naeku - who were drawing water from a well by the river bed. The girls told them that they have to walk a far distance to get water and then spend 30 minutes filling a 10-liter jerrican. Climate change-induced droughts forces these girls to spend a huge portion of their day acquiring clean water, missing vital hours that could be spent on learning.

These are the real effects of climate change, it is on us tackle climate change so that girls can access their right to education and realize their full potential.

With our educational sessions in schools and out of school, we leverage the power of storytelling to drive change to ensure that girls and boys can learn how to build an equitable world. Through our advocacy work, we partner with governmental organizations and community partners to bring awareness to harmful gender stereotypes and collaborate to remove barriers, such as climate change related inequities, in the way of girls’ education.

Future Rising Fellow, Nepal Tashi Lhuzom (@hashtag_tashi) participated in a post-COP27 Round Table Discussion hosted by UNESCO, United Nations Information Centre and United Nations Volunteers, where she discussed the important role that young people can play in ensuring the resolutions made at this year's COP27 are implemented.

At #COP27 governments took the ground-breaking decision to establish new funding arrangements and a a dedicated fund to assist developing countries in responding to loss and damage due to climate change. Governments also agreed to establish a transitional committee to make recommendations on how to operationalize both the new funding arrangements and the fund at #COP28 next year.

Tashi lives in a village only six kilometers from a glacier lake, which is on the verge of bursting due to rapid temperature rise. In 2013, her family lost all their animals and property of four generations in an avalanche. She says, "My village is not in threat of climate change in the future, but it is constantly at the risk even today."

With aspirations to become a political scientist and policy makers, Tashi is determined to play a role in protecting her community and advocating for their rights, urging world leaders to take immediate actions to reduce the impacts on the most marginalized communities in the world. Her climate awareness campaigns will soon include a film she is producing in the local Indigenous language.

This year, make a New Year's resolution that creates ripple effects around the world.

Click on the link in our bio to see how you can get involved with Girl Rising's efforts to advocate for girls' education worldwide.

Según datos del Observatorio de Salud Reproductiva (OSAR) en Guatemala, hasta septiembre del 2022 se han registrado 51,888 nacimientos que corresponden a niñas y adolescentes menores de 19 años y de éstas se han identificado 26 muertes maternas. En 2022, hubo al menos 1,584 embarazos en niñas y adolescentes de Sololá. Los embarazos en adolescentes representan riesgos a la salud física y mental de las niñas madres, y es poco probable que terminen de estudiar.

¡Exijamos estudios de calidad y accesibles para todas las niñas y adolescentes! Como papá, puedes apoyar a tus hijas a seguir estudiando.

Ser papá es educar
¡Únete a los hombres que le apuestan a la educación de sus hijas!

#YesToEducation #EducationIsARight #GirlsInSchool #SíALaEducación #DerechoALaEducación #NiñasEnLaEscuela

Equal access to Scooties! This is a small, but powerful outcome of Girl Rising's program and our work to build social-emotional skills in Alwar, Rajasthan, India.  Girls participating our program there are challenging gender norms and forging new paths for themselves. This two-wheeler, known as a Scooty by the locals, is typically only associated with boys and men. It's almost unheard of to have girls in the community using their own mode of transport and even when they do it's usually bicycles and not the more advanced Scooties.

Empowered by the voice, agency, and self-advocacy skills that they built in the Girl Rising programming, girls in Alwar are breaking many intergenerational cycles of stereotypes, healing their community, and boldly creating new pathways for girls and women. Click on the link in our bio to learn more about Girl Rising programs that are giving girls the tools to change the world.

As a young boy, Raini Sydney, Future Rising Fellow, Kenya, (swipe left to see image) witnessed his grandmother's masterful farming techniques - tilling, planting, spraying, and harvesting wheat and maize sustainably without any machinery. Over the years, he realized that the ancient wisdom and intuitive agricultural practices among the women in Kenya must be preserved and passed down. Knowledge such as recognizing when soil is best suited for planting based on its scent and identifying beneficial or harmful insects is indispensable to women like his grandmother, but has been disappearing as mass commercial farming becomes the norm. Raini saw that many modern farming techniques, while convenient, were also worsening climate change and introducing harmful chemicals that impacted rural farms like his grandmothers.

Raini is currently producing his Future Rising project, a documentary telling the stories of female rural smallholder farmers, like his grandmother, who draw on ancestral knowledge and natural solutions to fight climate change and build climate-resilient agricultural practices. To follow more of Raini's work follow him @orsydney

We love seeing girl advocates in action! Bishop Guertin High School Girls’ Basketball Team in New Hampshire brought together over 250 people, in collaboration with the Saint Anselm College New Hampshire Institute of Politics, for a special screening and discussion of the Girl Rising film. The team also fundraised for Girl Rising's education programs which reach millions of girls in eight countries.

Girl-led advocacy is an important part of Girl Rising social programs. If you want to get involved through your school, check out our Student Ambassador program in the link in our bio.

Congratulations to Future Rising Fellow Hilda Flavia Nakabuye (@nakabuyehildaflavia), for being one of the expert voices featured in The Climate Book, a collective non-fiction book directed by the climate activist Greta Thunberg. Hilda is featured along with other acclaimed contributors such as Handmaid's Tale famed writer Margaret Atwood,  Director General of the World Health Organization Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, American journalist David Wallace-Wells, Norwegian psychologist and politician Per Espen Stoknes, climate activists such as Hindou Oumarou Ibrahim, Disha Ravi, Ayisha Siddiqa, Mitzi Jonelle Tan and many others.

Hilda has been a vocal advocate for climate justice, recognizing that residents of the Global South, women, and children are disproportionately impacted by the climate crisis. In her writing, she boldly calls out the big polluters concentrated in the Global North and details steps that the world can take to stop the negative trend in climate change. For your copy of The Climate Book, click on the link in our bio.

Education is the most powerful way to prevent early and forced marriage. Each year of secondary education may reduce the likelihood of girls marrying before the age of 18 by 5% or more in many countries. Click on the link in our bio to learn how Girl Rising is building programs to promote girls' education globally.

Source: UNICEF, World Bank

Today, we are in the midst of a global crisis in girls’ education due to barriers that have increased with the pandemic, conflict, and natural disasters. Fathers play a vital role in supporting their daughters and ensuring they have access to education. Daughters whose fathers encourage them to finish school and fulfill their dreams are more likely to complete secondary school and higher education. We encourage fathers globally to join our efforts in advocating that girls everywhere can learn, rise, and thrive.

Tener una buena comunicación en familia es importante. Puedes animar a tus hijas a seguir adelante con sus estudios y sus sueños.

Ser papá es educar. ¡Únete a los hombres que le apuestan a la educación de sus hijas!
#SíALaEducación #DerechoALaEducación #NiñasEnLaEscuela

There is no age minimum to start changing the world. At just eight years old, Georgina Magesa from Tanzania is one of our youngest student ambassadors and a vocal climate advocate in her community. She applied her love of reading, writing, and the environment to founding a non-profit called Read and Green that assists children in their literary skills and teaches them how to keep the environment safe for future generations. Georgina is the author of two books - one, titled Georgina in Zanzibar, tells the stories of her adventures in the Tanzanian city, weaving in climate action lessons. Her second book, Georgina Na Mazingira, explores her love of nature and her dreams to protect it. Georgina's third book is already in the works.

Thank you Georgina for being an inspiration for aspiring young climate advocates all over the world! Follow her at @read_and_green to keep up with her journey and read more about her books.

Solola Department in Guatemala has been one of the places hardest hit by the global education crisis. In 2022, 23,000 adolescents from Sololá city, Guatemala, did not attend school. Girls make up the majority of young people missing from the classroom which increases their risk of experiencing violence, including unwanted pregnancies and forced marriage.

Let's demand quality and accessible education for all adolescents, especially girls! Join Girl Rising in advocating for girls’ education as we work with fathers around the world to support their daughters’ education and challenge gender barriers. 

En 2022, 23 mil niñas y adolescentes en edad de estudiar en Sololá, no asistieron a la escuela (MINEDUC, 2022). Esto aumenta el riesgo de que vivan violencia, incluyendo embarazos no deseados y matrimonio forzado.

¡Exijamos estudios de calidad y accesibles para todas las niñas y adolescentes! Como papá, puedes apoyar a tus hijas a seguir estudiando.
¡Únete a los hombres que le apuestan a la educación de sus hijas!

#SíALaEducación #DerechoALaEducación #NiñasEnLaEscuela

On this day, we remember Martin Luther King Jr. and his immeasurable contributions to civil rights and the fight for equality.

#MartinLutherKingDay is the only federal holiday in the United States designated as a National Day of Service to encourage all individuals to volunteer to improve their communities. Share how you may be #HonoringMLK through service today in the comments - and inspire others to do the same.

In the start of a new year, let’s cancel harmful practices like gender stereotypes, neglecting the climate and others’ human rights. Instead let’s usher in actions that help build a safer and more equitable world. Tell us in the comments what’s on your list.

Girl Rising and our partner 1 Million Teachers (@onemillionteachers) were proud hosts of a graduation ceremony in Nairobi, Kenya for 30 inspiring teachers who completed our online program training on gender bias in classrooms. This interactive and gamified training equips teachers on with an ability to recognize gender bias, to build lesson plans and classroom structures that tackle harmful stereotypes, to teach how to self-advocate.

This year, Girl Rising is expanding this online training to new regions of Africa. Congratulations to the training graduates!

Future Rising Fellow Tashi Lhazaom, Nepal, (@hashtag_tashi) joined a group of 10th-grade students at the Shree Krishna Higher Secondary government school to share her passion for youth advocacy and action to tackle  the climate crisis. Tashi has witnessed the impact of steadily melting glaciers in Nepal her entire life, and is living through climate change impacts on her community's agricultural economy.  In Tashi's view, girls are never to young to advocate for action.

Young people, particularly girls, are at highest risk of harm related to climate-related disasters.  In the wake of climate disasters, girls face heightened risk of violence and harm. That why it's critical that girls and the rest of the world advocate for climate plans include immediate action that prioritizes girls and women, following climate shocks. Here are some steps that young people can take right now to advocate for the climate:

✅ Educate themselves on the impacts of climate change.
✅ Use their social media and other platforms to educate others and advocate for serious action.
✅ Volunteer with climate advocacy groups and nonprofits.

Each year of schooling increases a girl’s potential for career options, the ability to raise a healthy family, and participation in community and civic life.

Let's demand quality and accessible education for all girls! Click on the link in our bio to learn more about Girl Rising’s work to create a world where all girls learn, rise, and thrive.

Girl Rising is hiring a Research and Data Scientist! Join our global team of talented, passionate changemakers who are advancing girls right to a quality education. Girl Rising has an exemplary culture of collaboration and creativity, and a strong sense of purpose and action.

Check out the job description via the link in our bio!

Education is a human right, a public good, and a public responsibility. Today, on this fifth #InternationalDayofEducation, Girl Rising pledges to double down on our work to break the barriers to girls education in collaboration with the tens of thousands of committed and compassionate educators we work with around the world. 
Girl Rising joins with the UNESCO dedicating this day to all the girls and women in Afghanistan who have been denied the right to learn, study and teach.

On this International Day of Education, invest in better a world by becoming a monthly donor via the link in our bio!

#EducationDay

Dreams and hopes of girls and women in Afghanistan have been ripped away. Their fundamental #RightToEducation has been violated. This is unacceptable. On #EducationDay, join our call to #LetAfghanGirlsLearn!

Repost @unesco
130 million girls are missing from classrooms around the world. But together, we can change that. Join Wings, Girl Rising's community of monthly donors and help girls soar via the link in our bio!

As a father, you can support your daughters' right to education. In Sololá, Guatemala, 5 out of 10 Indigenous girls who attend primary school go on to 7th-9th grade, and only half attend high school. Together we can advocate for all girls and boys to complete their education and go on to improve the prosperity of their communities.

Betty Khakoni, a 20-year-old alumnus of Girl Rising’s Kenya partner Big Picture Learning (BPLK / @kenya_big_picture_learning), is advancing a much-needed movement for sexual reproductive rights education in the informal settlement of Kawangware in Nairobi. Betty’s project is a response to a report by the Ministry of Health Kenya that recorded over 45,000 cases of teen pregnancies in January and February of 2022.

Betty graduated from BPLK's Kuna Nuru Leadership Academy. Translated from Swahili, Kuna Nuru means There Is Light. Kuna Nuru trains high school grads in community leadership skills and facilitates a project of their choice to address an important problem in their community.

Young women like Betty, who are geared with education and the resources that Girl Rising programs provide, are vital forces of change for a better tomorrow. Click on the link in our bio to learn more about how we are supporting adolescents in reaching their full potential.

Girl Rising Student Ambassadors and university students Blen Mamo and Mervielle Umulisa in Kigali, Rwanda led a film screening and discussion of LFG (@lfgthemovie), the award-winning documentary that follows women athletes and their fight for equal pay. They invited their fellow students at the African Leadership University who were inspired by the athletes’ dogged determination and used Girl Rising resources to discuss how they can advocate for girls’ and women’s rights.

Here are some of the inspirited quotes from some of the students who were part of the event:

"For the vision of equality, women can and should stand for themselves and let their voices be heard, while men must understand that women are far more capable than what we portray them."
-- Shema Fred, a student at the African Leadership University

"Through Girl Rising, which is on a mission to use the power of storytelling to change the way the world values girl's education, I couldn't be more delighted and proud to be participating in helping other girls all over the world get the education they deserve so they can achieve their dreams."
-- Meymuna Awad Idris, a Girl Rising Student Ambassador

"Women's empowerment goes beyond fighting for equality; between women, it can be a yearning and a decision by every woman to give out and take in from other women. As women, we have an affinity which blends into harmony. Organizing the LFG Screening at the African Leadership University was a step to satisfying that yearning and making the decision to share, laugh, empathize and normalize women's empowerment in our community."
-- Merveille Umulisa, a student at the African Leadership University and Girl Rising Student Ambassador

Today marks the start of Black History Month, a time dedicated to celebrating the contributions of people of the African diaspora - stories of individuals and groups that have been erased or excluded because of discrimination and racism.

This month, on our social platforms Girl Rising will honor trailblazing Black leaders and students who are currently leading change and fighting for justice - especially in the areas of access to quality education, gender rights, and environmental justice. Join us in celebrating the achievements of these pioneers and amplifying the voices of those who are transforming the world.

Black women in sports have historically combated multiple barriers and discrimination due to their gender and race. Trailblazers such as Sprinter Wilma Rudolph, Tennis Player Althea Gibson, High Jump Athlete Alice Coachman
and Basketball Player Lynette Woodard (@thelynettewoodard) helped pave the way for later generations of sports greats like Track and Field Athlete Jackie Joyner-Kersee (@jjoynerkersee), Basketball Player Sheryl Swoopes (@airswoopes22) and Tennis Players Venus (@venuswilliams) and Serena Williams (@serenawilliams).

Black women athletes have long shouldered the burden of excelling at their sport as well as educating the masses on issues of equity. In the past two decades, issues of racism, sexism and equality have been thrust into the public discourse due to the actions of Black women in sports, committed to creating a more just world for those who come after them. We celebrate the accomplishments of these women athletes in the sports field and out.

Join Girl Rising in advocating fair access for all athletes and honoring the efforts of these changemakers.

Meet Marissa Aroy Girl Rising’s Editorial Director of Future Rising. Marissa plays an integral role in helping Future Rising Fellows use storytelling to advocate for important gender and climate action plans.

Maríssa is an Emmy award-winning filmmaker who focuses on telling a compelling story, finding the right medium for the content, and capturing and engaging a targeted audience. From concept to completion, she has created and produced both short and long-form media across various platforms, working independently or with large production crews of over 30 people. A Fulbright Scholar, she has been an Adjunct Teaching Fellow at Trinity Dublin College and a Part-Time Faculty Member at The New School teaching documentary production in the Julien J. Studley Graduate Programs in International Affairs.
 

Our program provides the Fellows with committed and experienced advisors like Marissa, who help shape their stories into prolific transformative advocacy pieces. Click on the link in our bio to learn more about our Future Rising Program!

IMPORTANT: COVID-19 lockdowns have created a new challenge in the fight to end Female Genital Mutilation (FGM) as girls are often stuck in homes with those who are likely to impose this practice on them. Without action, by 2030 we could see as many as 2 million FGM cases that could otherwise have been avoided.

FGM is a grave human rights violation and on this International Day of Zero Tolerance for FGM we demand world leaders and organizations take serious measures to eradicate this practice.

Source: UNDP, UN Women

Girl Rising is in Mexico! We are thrilled to launch our new Financial Education program in partnership with Credit Suisse (creditsuisse_group | creditsuisse_ch) and in collaboration with local partners CIAM and Glasswing (@glasswingi). The new curriculum, developed with Aflatoun (@aflatoun_international), aims to build financial literacy along with life skills such as voice, agency, goal setting, and gender-equitable attitudes. As part of the program, we'll be engaging with parents and caregivers through workshops to build awareness of social and economic rights. This year our programming in Mexico will reach 3,000 adolescent girls and 3,000 caregivers in México City, León, Los Mochis, Tijuana and Cancún.

Last week, 9-year old Bobbi Wilson was honored as a Donor Scientist by Yale School of Public Health in a ceremony showcasing the budding scientist's recent work with managing the overpopulation of spotted lanternflies, an extremely invasive species that are harmful to trees and other plants. Yale entered Bobbi's collection of 27 spotted lanternflies into the Peabody Museum of Natural History database.

This honor comes just three months after Bobbi was wrongly reported to the police by a white neighbor who claimed he was frightened by her activities.  Bobbi was spraying homemade insect repellent on trees in her neighborhood as a part of New Jersey state's  Stomp It Out! campaign when her neighbor called the police. Stomp It Out! urges residents to help eradicate the spotted lanternfly infestation.

After the police stop, there has been an outpouring of support for Bobbi and her love of science and many have called racial profiling and stereotypes that often keep girls of color from boldly exploring and pursuing their passions. "Yale doesn't normally do anything like this ... This is something unique to Bobbi," said Ijeoma Opara, the Yale professor who helped organize the ceremony honoring her. "We wanted to show her bravery and how inspiring she is, and we just want to make sure she continues to feel honored and loved by the Yale community."

Bobbi's story is an example of the staggering barriers that girls and women of color face to succeed in their desired fields. We urge the global community to partner with girls in combatting the harmful subconscious biases standing in their way.

Picture Credit: Andrew Hurley/Yale University

Girl Rising’s grant partner, The Sean Connery Foundation, brought together leaders in environmental conservation at an event in Nassau city in The Bahamas to explore solutions to protect the world’s oceans. Future Rising Senior Fellow Lauren Ritchie presented about storytelling’s role in climate activism. Lauren, a Bahamas native, described the devastation that her family witnessed during Hurricane Dorian and urges swift and large-scale climate action.

Lauren is currently leading a Future Rising project that engages middle school girls to use the power of storytelling for climate advocacy. She noticed very early in her advocacy work that the data and numbers surrounding the climate crisis seemed lost on large numbers of people. However, story-based advocacy helped humanize the crisis and emphasized the urgency of the issue. To learn more about Lauren’s  work follow her @laurenaritchie

Fathers play a key role in their daughters’ education, supporting them economically and emotionally; helping them confront gender stereotypes, and by being a strong ally. Join Girl Rising and the global community of fathers who are rising up to advocate for girls’ education globally.

Click on the link in our bio to see how Girl Rising is making education more accessible for girls.

Los papás pueden jugar un papel muy importante en la educación de sus hijas, apoyándola económicamente y emocionalmente.

Ser papá es educar. ¡Únete a los hombres que le apuestan a la educación de sus hijas!

#SíALaEducación #DerechoALaEducación #NiñasEnLaEscuela

As Turkey and Syria navigate the devastating impacts of the deadly earthquake, the world must act quickly in support of the people of these nations. Girl Rising stands with the people of Turkey and Syria, especially with the girls and women disproportionately impacted by this natural disaster.

We call on world leaders and governments to act quickly to make all necessary financial and humanitarian assistance available to those affected by the unfolding crisis.

Black women have overcome deep-seated racial and gender biases and barriers to make valuable contributions to science. In honor of International Day of Women and Girls in Science and Black History Month, we celebrate these Black women in STEM.

Despite the progress in diversity in STEM, we recognize the underrepresentation of Black people in science-related fields. Black Americans make up only 9% of science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM) workers, and just 6% of research and professional STEM doctorate degree recipients, according to the 2021 Pew Research Center study.

We urge education and government leaders to increase access and pipelines for more Black individuals to excel in science.

social_posts.post_text:
Dorceta Taylor, Ph.D. is a Yale-educated environmental sociologist, historian, writer, academic, and the first-ever Black woman to receive a doctoral degree from the university’s School of Forestry and Environmental Studies. In her impressive career, she has effectively brought attention to environmental racism in governmental climate policies and the lack of diversity in environmental organizations.

People of color only make up about 28 percent of all American STEM workers. This often leads to people of color and their needs being left out of climate protections. Her report “State of Diversity in Environmental Organizations” dove into the intersection of gender, racial, and class diversity within NGOs, foundations, and government agencies. She further explored this in her 2014 award-winning book Toxic Communities which takes a deeper look at the impact of environmental racism on Black communities. She continues to hold nonprofit and government agencies accountable for inclusion in staffing environmental protection roles.

In an interview with the University of Michigan she is quoted as powerfully saying, "In King's day, we fought to drink from the same fountain. Today we fight to drink the same quality water”.

Men and boys are critical allies for girls’ and women’s rights. Fathers particularly play a key role in changing generations of ideas on how girls and women are seen and supporting their daughters' highest aspirations.

Advocate girls’ right to education in your community. Join Girl Rising and the global community of dads who are rising up to advocate for girls’ education globally.

Ser papá es educar y puedes aprender junto a tus hijas. Pregúntale sobre sus sueños y lo que está aprendiendo en la escuela. ¡Únete a los hombres que le apuestan a la educación de sus hijas!

#SíALaEducación #DerechoALaEducación #NiñasEnLaEscuela

Barbara Johns, a courageous changemaker at just 16 years old, led a historic student walkout at Robert Russa Moton High School in 1951 to demand equal educational opportunities for Black students. 
At the time, her high school was segregated, overcrowded and woefully underfunded. She boldly organized a protest of her school’s inequality by convincing the entire student body to walk
out of school together to protest at City Hall. Her actions garnered the support of the NAACP who filed a suit on her behalf, which was eventually bundled into the landmark Brown V. Board of Education.Her bravery and determination continue to inspire future generations to fight for educational equity.

Barbara Johns blazed a trail for educational equity.
We honor her by continuing to fight for a world where all young people can learn, rise and thrive.
#BlackHistoryMonth #LearnRiseThrive #EducationalEquity #GirlRising #trailblazers
No greater expression of love than building a more equitable world together! Tag your gender-norm-challenging besties in the comments of this virtual Valentine. 🙌 ❤️

Meet Jay'Aina "Jay Jay" Patton, a 17-year-old app developer, social justice advocate, and Girl Rising ambassador, who developed an app with her father, Antoine, that allows kids to upload photos and letters for their incarcerated parents.

Jay Jay was just 12 years old when she created her first app for her father's nonprofit, the Photo Patch Foundation. Her father, Antoine, started the nonprofit website when he was in prison and struggling to keep in contact with Jay Jay and other family members.

Jay Jay, now runs the Unlock Academy with her Father, an in-person and online coding school that mentors young people interested in STEM careers.

She will be taking over Girl Rising's Instagram on Thursday, February 16th, and showing you an inside view into the life of a teenage tech entrepreneur and social justice advocate. Don't miss it!

Jaylin Ward was just 20 years old when they co-founded two nonprofit organizations, mAK Collective and Generation Green that advocate for inclusive climate action.

Jaylin’s environmental passion took shape when they played a leadership role in reviving a community garden in Howard University, where they are a student. The garden became a sanctuary for Howard University students facing food insecurity, which spontaneously brought together a team of Black women and people in the LGBTQ+ community. Jaylin noticed that environmental liberation was at the crux of all social justice causes so they helped co-found Generation Green which is creating a global network of Black youth fighting the climate crisis through intersectional issues like period poverty, gender-based violence, and several other geographies.

In an interview with Refinery29 Jaylin said, “I recognize that my liberation, my safety, is contingent upon rebuilding community in a way that doesn’t rely upon scarcity, exploitation, extraction, and fossil fuels. I have no interest or intention of reincarnating on Earth, and I am doing everything in my power to show Black people that we can affect change and our own destinies.”

Follow @makcollective and @generation__green to learn more about and support Jaylin’s environmental advocacy.

We are excited to roll out our Financial Education program in Ghana! This 24-session curriculum will be implemented in partnership with Credit Suisse and our local partners Dels Foundation and The Exploratory. Together, we have been training 200 educators who will facilitate the Girl Rising programming with adolescent girls in schools.

The local partners are also being trained in partnership with George Washington University on measuring and evaluating the success of programs and the outcomes of girls. Scroll to the end to see a team-building exercise unique to our Ghanaian training sessions.

Girl Rising is hiring!

Join our global team of talented, passionate changemakers who are advancing girls right to a quality education. Girl Rising has an exemplary culture of collaboration and creativity, and a strong sense of purpose and action.

Check out the job description via the link in our bio!

Join us on Tuesday March 14th for a United Nations Committee on the Status of 
Women 67 Forum Parallel event. With vivid storytelling and solutions-focused conversations, Tipping the Scale features three Future Rising Fellows who will each share their deep experiences with climate crises and their urgent demands for climate justice and gender equity. Hilda Flavia Nakabuye (@nakabuyehildaflavia) of Uganda, Lauren Ritchie (@laurenaritchie) of The Bahamas, and Mercy Kamonjo (@mercywanjikukamonjo) of Kenya, will recount their personal stories of addressing climate impacts in their communities with scalable local solutions.

Spaces are limited. Click on the link in our bio to learn more.

social_posts.post_text:
In 2013, three bold Black organizers — Alicia Garza, Patrisse Cullors, and Opal Tometi — created a movement called #BlackLivesMatter in response to the acquittal of Trayvon Martin’s murderer, George Zimmerman. Zimmerman 
fatally shot unarmed Trayvon, a 17-year-old who was walking back home to his relative’s home after stopping by at a convenience store.

This project that started as a movement for justice for Trayvon is now a member-led global network of more than 40 chapters across the United States. The members organize and advocate against violence inflicted on Black
communities by the state and vigilantes.

The organizers describe Black Lives Matter as “an ideological and political intervention in a world where Black lives are systematically and intentionally targeted for demise. It is an affirmation of Black folks’ humanity, our contributions to this society, and our resilience in the face of deadly oppression.”

This World Social Justice Day, we recognize the important work that the Black Lives Matter movement has done in shining a light on the fact that Black individuals are often unfairly targeted and harmed. We stand with the movement and strongly condemn the racial bias and violent actions that have cost the life of many Black people including Trayvon Martin, George Floyd, Breonna Taylor and countless 
others. We urge government leaders to implement stronger protections to teach the
impacts of subconscious bias, prevent such senseless acts of violence and hold guilty
parties accountable.

Meet Girl Rising champion and 11-year-old sports journalist Pepper Persley, one of Adweek's 2022 Most Powerful Women in Sports. Last summer alone, Pepper hosted a Title IX panel for Nike, reported courtside for the WNBA Champion Las Vegas Aces, reported live from the MLB Little League Classic for ESPN, and tookover WNBA Seattle Storm's Instagram. She has also moderated panels with Girl Rising and served as the host of our new series On the Rise featuring game-changing girls from all around the world.

She will taking over Girl Rising's Instagram and providing a unique inside look into her world on Thursday, February 23rd. Don't miss it!

Happy International Mother Language Day! Today we celebrate the diversity of languages and cultures around the world. Did you know that this day was first recognized as a tribute to the students in Bangladesh who bravely fought for their right to use their mother tongue, Bengali? Access to information in one's native language is crucial, especially when it comes to issues like climate action.

Check out our blog post featuring insights from Future Rising Fellow Titas Ganguly (@titasnganguly) on the vital connection between language and building resilient communities in the face of the climate crisis. Click the link in our bio to read more.

Sarah and Shirley Bulah (pictured above), mother and daughter, made history in the state of Delaware by fighting for their right to equal education. In the 1950s, they were denied enrollment in a white school in Wilmington, Delaware because of their race, and instead Shirley had to travel three hours each day to attend an underfunded all Black school. Instead of accepting this discrimination, they decided to take legal action. With the help of the NAACP, they filed a lawsuit against the school board and the state of Delaware. The case, Bulah v. Gebhart, was one of the five cases that were combined and heard as Brown v. Board of Education of Topeka, Kansas in 1954. This landmark ruling by the United States Supreme Court declared that the segregation of schools was unconstitutional and helped to end legal discrimination in education. The Bulah's courage and determination in standing up
for their rights helped to bring about a more just and equal society for all. They are an inspiration to us all and a reminder of the power of individuals to effect change and make a difference.

Mother and daughter Sarah and Shirley blazed a trail for educational equity. We honor their courage by continuing to fight for a world where all young people can learn, rise and thrive. #BlackHistoryMonth #LearnRiseThrive #EducationalEquity #GirlRising #trailblazers

Engaging with community organizations and enlisting new partners to support Girl Rising's goal to challenge gender norms  is an essential part of the success of our work globally. Recently, our Kenya team participated in an event hosted by the Kenya National Museums that brought together over 400 attendees and 30 education-focused organizations during which we shared how our program helps adolescents build voice and agency, and develop self-advocacy skills. The event is in collaboration with the Kenyan government's effort to create more equitable learning experiences and environments.

In celebration of Black History Month, we recognize Clarice Phelps, the first Black woman to help discover an element. Clarice's contribution was critical in filling a vacant spot in the seventh row of the periodic table. This element, now officially recognized as Element 117, was created through a painstaking, months-long process of purifying the element berkelium and bombarding it with calcium.

As a Black woman in science, Clarice faced many challenges and had very few role models who looked like her. However, she is determined to change that for future generations of Black girls. "I want to be that person for that little girl who’s looking for somebody that looks like them, doing things that people say they can’t do.” Let's celebrate Clarice's groundbreaking achievement and her commitment to being a role model for young Black girls in STEM!

Photo courtesy of Calvin Mattheis/The Knoxville News Sentinel/USA Today Network

SOLA is the first and only Afghan-led boarding school for Afghan girls. Started in Kabul, the school has relocated to Rwanda after the Taliban took control of Afghanistan in 2021. 

It is now illegal for girls to attend school past 6th grade in Afghanistan – making the need for SOLA and the opportunities it provides greater than ever. 

We hope you will tune in on Sunday at 7pm EST to watch a 60 Minutes segment about this remarkable school and it’s remarkable leader, Shabana Basij-Rasikh, who we are honored to have as part of our Advisory Council. 
@sola.afghanistan @60minutes @sbasijrasikh #sola #Afghanistan #Rwanda #Girlseducation #dontlookaway

Meet Hilda Flavia Nakabuye (@nakabuyehildaflavia), Future Rising Fellow, climate justice advocate, author and one of the speakers at our Tipping the Scale event. Hilda is fast becoming one of Uganda’s most prominent youth climate and environmental rights activists. Her work combines local and grassroots environmental work with advocacy and campaigning on the world’s biggest stages.  She founded Uganda's Fridays for Future movement and has spoken at major global convenings around the world to advocate for climate justice including COP27 and UNGA Transforming Education Summit and COP40 in Buenos Aires. At home, she leads a nationwide team of environmental justice activists who conduct training and advocacy and lead regular clean up operations around Lake Victoria as well as collaborations with schools and local communities to empower young people to fight against environmental degradation and climate change.

She will be speaking at Tipping the Scale, a United Nations Commission on the 
Status of Women parallel event, where she will share her personal experience with addressing climate impact in her community with scalable local solutions. Learn more about the event in the link in our bio!

“Black Land Matters.” With these words, Leah Penniman begins her revolutionary book Farming While Black, which tackles deep vulnerabilities in our food system that show environmental racism.

Leah noticed that historically Black and Brown communities have low access to fresh produce. She came up dry on her own search for fresh options in her neighborhood, which had only a corner store, a liquor store and a McDonalds. To remedy her own needs she started a farm that eventually grew into a movement called Soul Fire Farm, a BIPOC (Black, Indigenous, and people of color)-centered community farm in Grafton, New York, that is dedicated to ending racism and injustice in the food system.

Leah establishes food scarcity as a serious threat for Black and Brown communities. She pitches that the solutions to many food scarcity and climate crisis issues could be solved by tapping into the ancestral knowledge of Black and Indigenous people. To learn more about Leah's work follow @SoulFireFarm

Photo credit: Jamel Mosely

Fathers can play a vital role in breaking gender barriers for their daughters. They can challenge stereotypes, call out bias, encourage their daughters’ aspirations and support their education.

Let's demand quality and accessible education for all girls and adolescents! Join Girl Rising and the global community of dads who are rising up to advocate for girls’ education globally.

Como hombre y padre de familia, puedes cambiar tu forma de pensar. Es importante ver y creer que las mujeres y hombres tenemos las mismas capacidades y los mismos derechos. ¡Únete a los hombres que le apuestan a la educación de sus hijas!

 #SíALaEducación #DerechoALaEducación #NiñasEnLaEscuela

Johnnetta B. Cole is a trailblazer in the world of education and civil rights. She was the first Black woman to serve as president of both Spelman College and Bennett College, two historically Black women's colleges. During her tenure at Spelman, she increased enrollment, established new programs, and raised millions of dollars in funding. She was a strong advocate for diversity and inclusion, and worked to make the campus a more welcoming place for students of all backgrounds. In addition to her work in higher education, Dr. Cole has also been a prominent leader in the civil rights movement. Her contributions to education and civil rights have made a significant impact, and she continues to inspire and empower people to this day.

Johnnetta B. Cole blazed a trail for educational equity. We honor her achievements by continuing to fight for a world where all young people can learn, rise and thrive.

#BlackHistoryMonth #LearnRiseThrive #EducationalEquity #GirlRising

Today is Zero Discrimination Day, a day dedicated to promoting equality and celebrating diversity. Did you know that 1 in 5 people globally reports being discriminated against? Girls and women are overwhelmingly represented in that number. But the good news is that we can all take action to end discrimination.

It will take collective action from world governments, communities, and individuals to make a real difference. Let’s stand up for what is right and work together to build a world where everyone is treated with respect and dignity. It’s on us to end discrimination! #ZeroDiscriminationDay #EquityForAll

March 8th is International Women's Day! Join us on that day in celebrating the remarkable achievements of women throughout history by sharing this image and telling us in the caption the vital  role women play in communities around the world. Then tag a friend to do the same.

Let's unite to shine a light on the importance of women and the critical need to break down barriers that still hold women back from reaching their full potential. Let's use our individual and collective power to rise up and create a better world for all.

Click on the link in our bio to download the graphic or share this post directly.
#IAmWomanRising #InternationalWomensDay.

Meet Mercy Wanjiku Kamonjo (@mercywanjikukamonjo), Future Rising Fellow, Kenyan environmentalist and food security activist and one of the speakers at our Tipping the Scale event. Mercy  is the founder of the Kuza Generation Initiative, a youth-led nonprofit organization that empowers rural communities struggling with the impacts of climate change. Mercy provides training for women and girls living in arid and semi-arid areas on how to use resilient Climate Smart Agriculture techniques such as vertical and sack gardening using reclaimed materials that increase farm productivity as much as 400%.

Mercy will be speaking at Tipping the Scale, a United Nations Commission on the Status of Women parallel event, where she will share her personal experience leading scalable local solutions. Learn more about the event in the link in our bio!

When you teach girls about voice and agency they tap into the strength within themselves to advocate for fair access for themselves and their communities. Recently, we saw an example of this in Vasha (name changed) from Varanasi, India, an alumnus of our partner Milaan Foundation's (@milaan_foundation) programming. When she witnessed a peer in the 8th class being forced into child marriage she called India's Childline helpline and local police to register a complaint of child marriage. The authorities were able to intervene quickly and remove the child from a harmful situation. Vasha's courage and quick thinking was praised in an article in the local Hindi newspaper.

According to The National Family Health Survey data, almost 16% of girls are subjected to child marriage in Uttar Pradesh, negatively influencing the girls in the community and stripping them of their rights to education, health, and protection. It is imperative we continue to give young girls a voice to advocate for themselves and their peers so they can be changemakers in their community.

Rise with us this Wednesday, March 8th, on International Women's Day to celebrate the multi-faceted roles that women play in society. Unite with us to break down the barriers that still hold women back from reaching their full potential.

We invite all advocates for gender equity and women's rights to download the image in our bio and share your ideas and stories in your social media posts highlighting both the vital role women play in society and in the barriers world organizations and individuals can help break down. Don't forget to use the hashtag #IAmWomanRising in your post.

"Remember that no matter where you are, it’s women and girls who are affected worst. So, put women at the center of your work. Advocate for rural women. Put your attention into LOCAL work - because it’s local initiatives like Kuza Generation that are making a difference for people who are worst impacted - not in the future - but now."

Future Rising Fellow Mercy Wanjiku Kamonjo's call to action on Sunday March, 5 at the @AspenIdeas: Climate, the Future Leaders Climate Summit.  Mercy (@Kamonjo_mercy), along with Fellows Tia Kennedy (@kiinewkwe), Hilda Flavia Nakabuye (@nakabuyehildaflavia), and Lauren Ritchie (@laurenaritchie), and Girl Rising CEO Christina Lowery - all demanding to make girls’ education a central part of our efforts to address climate change.

#AspenIdeasClimate #MiamiBeach #FutureLeadersClimate #FLCS2023

Komal in Rajasthan, India, began participating in the Girl Rising program two-years go and today she is on a mission to help all the girls in her region build voice and agency, and develop their self-advocacy skills. Girl Rising’s Social Emotional Learning (SEL) sessions have been instrumental in empowering young girls like Komal to dream big and reach for their aspirations. Growing up in a farming family, Komal lacked the resources to pursue her education beyond her village. However, through the SEL sessions, she found the courage to dream again and discovered her passion for computer science and teaching.

As Komal grew more confident with each session, she began sharing her newfound knowledge with other girls in her village. Her passion for teaching and her desire to inspire young girls led her to hold weekly discussions with 35 girls. Komal believes that even a small shift in someone's life can make a significant impact. She never thought she could inspire anyone, but now she sees that she can be a role model for other young girls.

“I never thought I could inspire anyone or be a role model to anyone, but today when I hear these girls say that they want to become vocal like me, I know that this is the onset of a movement”.

Women are rising globally as transformative forces of positive change, we just need to remove the glass ceiling above them. This International Women’s Day, join us in bringing awareness to the vital role women play in society by downloading the image in our bio and sharing the role women have played in your world and one critical barrier we can collectively work to remove from their way. Don’t forget to use the hashtag #IAmWomanRising so our global community can see and share your important message.

Meet Naomi Ramos, Girl Rising's new Program Manager in Mexico. Born in Mexico City to Japanese and Mexican parents, Naomi holds a Bachelor’s degree in Social Psychology and a Master’s degree in Clinical Psychology. She has over 10 years of experience in international education at different universities in Mexico and the Fulbright program. She is also a trained therapist for women who experience gender based violence. Being the daughter of a woman who was the breadwinner in the family in a context where this was not the norm, Naomi grew up understanding the pressing need to bridge the gender equity gap in all spheres of women’s lives and sparked her passion to build agency in girls and women.

In her spare time, Naomi loves running, karaoke, board game nights and experimenting in the kitchen. She lives in Mexico City with her husband and two noisy but endearing dogs.

We honor the trailblazing women judges like Ruth Bader Ginsburg who have shattered glass ceilings to make room for themselves and have passed historic legislation that allows access for all women. This International Day of Women Judges we urge world governments to make more spaces for women in all bodies of government.

Spaces are running out for our Tipping the Scale event a parallel event at the United Nations Commission on the Status of Women 67. Don't miss out on your chance to be a part of the conversation and hear from Future Rising Fellows Hilda Flavia Nakabuye (@nakabuyehildaflavia), Lauren Ritchie (@laurenaritchie), Mercy Kamonjo (@Kamonjo_mercy), and Tia Kennedy (@kiinewkwe ), as they share their compelling stories of addressing climate crises in their communities, as well as GPE Global Advocacy Policy Lead, Sirtaj Kaur, who will share insights from their work centered around girls’ education and climate change.

Click on the link in our bio to register now!
