social_posts.post_text:
Girl Rising is hiring!

Join our global team of talented, passionate changemakers who are advancing girls right to a quality education. Girl Rising has an exemplary culture of collaboration and creativity, and a strong sense of purpose and action.

Check out the job description via the link in our bio!

Meet Lauren Ritchie (@laurenaritchie), a climate justice advocate, storyteller from The Bahamas and a speaker at our Tipping the Scale event on Tuesday. She is the founder of  The Eco Justice Project, a digital climate education platform which uplifts the voices of historically underrepresented and marginalized communities. She also co-hosts the society and pop-culture-centered podcast, Black Girl Blueprint. She recently graduated from Columbia University with a degree in Sustainable Development where she created the panel series, Columbia Climate Conversations, which brought activists and scientists of color to speak on environmental issues. Lauren is now continuing her Fellowship as a Senior Fellow with Future Rising.

Lauren will be speaking at Tipping the Scale, a United Nations Commission on the Status of Women parallel event, where she will share her personal experience leading scalable local solutions. Learn more about the event in the link in our bio!

Meet Tia Kennedy (@kiinewkwe) an Indigenous rights activist, youth leader in her community and a speaker at tomorrow's Tipping the Scale event. She comes from two First Nations communities. She carries Haudenosaunee and Anishinaabe teachings from Oneida Nation of the Thames and Walpole Island First Nation. Kennedy is the founder of Kiinew Kwe Consulting, a company that empowers organizations to address discrimination and develop the necessary skills, knowledge, attitudes and values to promote meaningful and effective interactions with Indigenous peoples.

Tia is an activist who advocates for Indigenous people’s right to clean water. During her Future Rising Fellowship with Girl Rising, she made a short that highlights the impact of the water crisis on her own family as well as the role that Indigenous women play as waterkeepers. Tia will share her personal experiences with harnessing ancient wisdom to lead sustainable climate solutions at Tipping the Scale, a United Nations Commission on the Status of Women parallel event. Learn more about the event in the link in our bio!

Michelle Yeoh (@michelleyeoh_official) made history last night as the first Asian American woman to win an Oscar and today she is using her international fame and respect to deliver a vital message about the importance of prioritizing women and girls in humanitarian response efforts in a powerful OpEd in the New York Times. She recounts her time in Nepal during the catastrophic 2015 earthquake. As we continue to navigate the aftermath of the disaster in Turkey and Syria, Michelle sounds the alarm on the overwhelming impact on girls and women in those communities.

“To fully recover from a disaster and be prepared for the next one, the specific needs of women and girls must be factored into the humanitarian response,” she writes, “We know women sustain their communities. Their voices, leadership, and full participation are key to an inclusive, successful, and sustainable recovery.”

Girl Rising congratulates Michelle Yeoh and we thank her for bringing international attention to the urgent need to prioritize gender equity.

Picture Credit: Patrick T. Fallon/AFP/Getty Images, Prakash Mathema/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

Meet Sirtaj Kaur, a speaker at today's Tipping the Scale event. Sirtaj has led the Global Partnership for Education’s (GPE) engagement in key policy forums including the Transforming Education Summit, G7, Generation Equality Forum and the UN General Assembly. She currently leads GPE’s advocacy engagement on climate change and food security. For the Generation Equality Forum, she drafted recommendations on behalf of an education sector-wide coalition, including on integrating education into the Feminist Action for Climate Justice action track, which were integrated into the main outcomes of the action tracks. She also developed a program on the Ripple Effects of Education for the Global Education Summit, bringing in key voices on education and climate change. In her previous role at Malala Fund, she launched Malala’s Film and Advocacy Campaign in India and led the grant making process for the grants in India. Sirtaj holds an MA from the Johns Hopkins University School of Advanced International Studies (SAIS) and a law degree from the Army Institute of Law, India.

Sirtaj will share insights from their work on girls' education and climate change. We hope to see you at Tipping the Scale today! To learn more about the event click on the link in our bio.

"Violence to our land is violence to our bodies. Let's stop the harm and start working together for an equitable world" Future Rising Fellow Tia Kennedy's (@kiinewkwe) call to action for global decision-makers to include the perspectives of those most impacted by climate change, and those who have working knowledge of solutions.  Yesterday Tia, and Future Rising Fellows Hilda Flavia Nakabuye (@nakabuyehildaflavia), Mercy Wanjiku Kamonjo (@Kamonjo_mercy), and Lauren Ritchie (@laurenaritchie), along with Girl Rising CEO Christina Lowery and GPE Global Advocacy Policy Lead, Sirtaj Kaur led Tipping Point, our special event as part of the 67th Session of the Commission on the Status of Women focused on girls' education as one of the world's most potent solutions to the climate crisis.

Meet the @RoseInc #DynamicDuo Nidhi and Lauren. Our corporate partner Rose Inc., recently featured Girl Rising's very own Global Head of Programs, Nidhi Shukla, and Senior Fellow Lauren Ritchie (@laurenaritchie), in their highly acclaimed "Dynamic Duo" series. This exclusive interview series brings together two highly influential individuals for an insightful conversation, and Nidhi and Lauren were the perfect duo for the job. Hailing from Delhi and The Bahamas respectively, Nidhi and Lauren may come from different worlds, but they share a common goal: to create a more equitable world. During the interview, they tackled complex issues such as climate change and gender bias, and shared their unique perspectives on overcoming these challenges. Their passion and dedication to building a better world are truly inspiring.

To read more about Nidhi and Lauren's remarkable stories and their visions for a brighter future, be sure to click on the link in our bio. Join us in celebrating their amazing achievements and commitment to making the world a better place.

Meet Andrea Coché the Co-executive Director of our partner organization MAIA (@maia_impact) in Guatemala. MAIA is led by Indigenous women for Indigenous women, that supports young women to create systemic change in their community through strong academics and socio-emotional development.

Andrea, a proud Indigenous Maya Tz'tujil woman, firmly believes in the infinite potential of girls and women to transform society. Growing up in an under-resourced community, she committed herself to advocating for the needs of her community, especially Indigenous women and children. As Co-Executive Director of MAIA, she works to ensure that all girls in Guatemala, particularly Indigenous girls, have access to resources that enable them to reach their full potential. MAIA Impacto School is the first Guatemalan school for Indigenous girls offering a unique environment that addresses their specific needs and helps overcome educational barriers. Girl Rising is proud to partner with organizations like MAIA and inspiring women leaders to break down barriers for girls and women. Visit maiagt.org to learn more about MAIA.

Note: Swipe left to see an illustration of Andrea featured in a magazine created by our team in Guatemala for their campaign on the importance of men supporting strong women.

One more time for the people in the back: Girls’ Education is the world’s most potent solution to climate change.

Click on the link in our bio to to learn more about our Future Rising Program that is helping harness the power of educated girls to tackle impacts of climate change in communities all over the world.

The liberation of all women often starts with women advocating for themselves. Click on the link in our bio to get involved with a global community of changemakers working to challenge the way girls and women are seen in the world.

Educated girls are often happy girls! This #InternationalDayofHappiness, help us spread more happiness in the world by advocating for girls' rights. Share this post and tell your community why you are standing up for girls' education today.

Despite discrimination and persistent gender barriers, women have always been shaping our world. This International Women's History Month, we recognize the extraordinary, talented and committed women leading some of our partner organizations. Many of these leaders had to overcome tremendous barriers to complete their education and build their career, and they are now investing in a new generation of young women. Girl Rising is honored to partner with these trailblazers.

@jigster__  @rooxierux @asekuna @1mtcares @onemillionteachers @slamoutloud @sunflower_global @sunflowerglobal

Did you know that in some parts of the world, girls spend up to 6 hours a day collecting water for their households? That's time they should be spending in classrooms, learning and growing. But a lack of water security and the increasing water crisis are huge barriers to girls' education, and we need to take action. Here are some amazing organizations that are working tirelessly to bring clean water to communities and break down this barrier:

💧 Water.org: This organization has brought clean water and sanitation to over 33 million people worldwide.
💧 Charitywater: 100% of donations go directly to clean water projects, and they've funded over 60,000 projects in 29 countries.
💧 Water for Good: This organization is working to bring sustainable, clean water sources to communities in the Central African Republic.

Let's come together to help ensure that every girl has the opportunity to get the education she deserves!

Motivated by her first-hand experience of a daughter with an incarcerated mother, in 2013 Brittany K. Barnett founded the non-profit Girls Embracing Mothers (GEM). Brittany is an activist, attorney, and author whose work in incarceration healing has empowered many families as they try to break the cycle of incarceration. GEM provides a unique partnership with the Texas Department of Criminal Justice, supporting women in prison and their daughters as they create relationships through the boundaries of prisons.

Read more of Brittany's inspirational personal story and about how @girlsembracingmothers is supporting girls separated from their incarcerated mothers in the link in our bio!

At the UN Water Conference 2023, Future Rising Fellow Lety Tituana, Ecuador introduced Warmi STEM, an initiative aimed at transforming vulnerable communities into sustainable ones. "We advocate for the leadership of rural girls and women to empower communities by addressing issues like poor water management. However, we need government support and belief in initiatives like Warmi STEM. We need government to support innovation to tackle climate crisis challenges. More women must lead such projects," Tituana emphasized.

Future Rising Fellows Lety (@lety_tp), Hilda Nakabuye (@nakabuyehildaflavia), Tia Kennedy (@kiinewkwe ), and Lauren Ritchie (@laurenaritchie) united at a UN parallel event, urging immediate action on the global water crisis. Co-hosted by Girl Rising, the United Nations Department of Economic and Social Affairs (UN DESA), and the Permanent Mission of Monaco to the UN, the event featured distinguished speakers, including Her Excellency Ms. Isabelle Picco, Ambassador of Monaco to the UN; Lotta Tahtinen, Chief of Outreach and Partnership Branch in the Division for Sustainable Development Goals at UN DESA; and Rashema Ingraham, Executive Director of Waterkeepers Bahamas. Christina Kwauk, a social scientist specializing in girls' education and climate change, moderated the event.

En la conferencia de ONU- Agua, Lety Tituana originaria de Ecuador y Fellow del programa Future Rising, introdujo Warmi STEM, una iniciativa orientada a transformar las comunidades vulnerables en comunidades sostenibles. “Defendemos el liderazgo de las niñas de áreas rurales y de las mujeres para empoderar comunidades al abordar problemáticas como el mal manejo de aguas. Necesitamos que el gobierno apoye la inovación para abordar los desafíos de la crisis climática. Más mujeres deben liderar proyectos”. Tituana enfatizó.

Fellows del programa Future Rising, Lety, Hilda Nakabuye, Tia Kennedy, y Lauren Ritchie unidas en la ONU Evento Paralelo, demandaron acción inmediata sobre la crisis global del agua. Co-liderado por Girl Rising, las Naciones Unidas Departamento de Asuntos Económicos y Sociales de Naciones Unidas (UN DESA), y la Mision Permanente de Mónaco en la ONU . . .

Parents play a vital role in ending harmful gender norms that keep girls out of school. This is why our educational partners Pakistan Alliance for Girls Education (PAGE) brough together parents and guardians of 9 to 15-year-olds in Islamabad and Lahore to engage them in a dialogue about the value educating girls can bring to their families and the community. Parents engaged in a series of sessions that equipped them with the appropriate strategies to facilitate their children’s social-emotional learning and gender bias training.

We applaud these guardians who are taking important steps to create more safe spaces for girls to get educated and feel supported to reach their full potential. To learn more about our inspiring partners @pagepakistan visit page.org.pk

In a powerful address at the UN Water Conference, Future Rising Fellow Hilda Flavia Nakabuye (@nakabuyehildaflavia), Uganda, called for urgent action to prioritize girls and women in the fight against the world’s water crises. Emphasizing the importance of gender equity, Nakabuye implored global leaders to prioritize solutions led by women and girls in order to address water scarcity and sanitation issues, and to ensure that girls and women always have a place at the negotiating table when addressing the world’s water crisis. Her speech followed a special parallel event at the UN Water conference, co-hosted by Girl Rising, the United Nations Department of Economic and Social Affairs, and the Permanent Mission of Monaco to the UN. Special thanks Ashley Bernhard and Haven Hill LLC for her invaluable contributions to making this event possible.  See Hilda’s speech here.

Throughout the month, Hilda and Future Rising Fellows Mercy Kamonjo (@kamonjo_mercy) from Kenya, Lauren Ritchie (@laurenaritchie) from The Bahamas, and Tia Kennedy (@kiinewkwe) from First Nations, Canada have participated in numerous high-profile international forums to raise awareness about the power of girls’ education as a critical solution to combat climate change and the related water crisis. To learn more about this event visit http://girlrising.org/unwaterevent2023.  #FutureRising #climatejustice #girlseducation

True allyship means advocating for women's rights beyond Women's History Month. Join Girl Rising in advocating for girls' and women's rights every day until gender parity is achieved. Click on the link in our bio to see how you can be involved.

This Women's History Month, while honoring trailblazing women leaders who've made remarkable strides towards gender equity, let's also applaud the educators who actively teach young minds to challenge gender bias and dismantle barriers to achieve global equality. Girl Rising is immensely grateful for our dedicated and passionate educators who collaborate with us and the children to eradicate gender bias in classrooms worldwide. Show appreciation for an educator in your life by tagging them in the comments below and thanking them for their incredible work.

#WomensHistoryMonth #GenderEquity #EducatorsMakeADifference

In early February when two back-to-back devastating earthquakes hit her home, Turkiye, Visual Artist, and Digital Illustrator Burcu Koleli quickly plunged into action by creating digital illustrations that raised awareness about the catastrophe. Now Burcu is working with the organization We Need to Talk to end the period taboo and poverty that is prevalent in communities surviving natural disasters.

Burcu is a vocal advocate for the links between climate change, natural disasters, and their disproportionate impact on girls and women. She is passionate about using art such as her gouache paintings and illustrations to educate people and push the needle on important issues.

Please click on the link in our bio to read Burcu’s moving first-person account of the experiences of Turkish immigrants in the United States during the devastating earthquakes in Turkey. Follow her @burcukoleli to see more of her work.

Future Rising Fellow, Uganda Hilda Flavia Nakabuye recently led her nonprofit Fridays for Future Uganda (@fridays4futureug) to a clean up of Lake Victoria in Africa.

Hilda has been a long-time advocate of saving Lake Victoria, an important water source for fishing communities and residents of five countries -- Rwanda, Burundi, Kenya, Tanzania, and Uganda. Climate change and water pollution have caused the lake to suffer degradation including loss of land cover, increasing soil erosion, declining soil fertility and agro-chemical pollution. This could have grave impacts on the lives of millions of people dependent on the lake. Hilda has been raising awareness, leading clean-up efforts, and boldly calling out corporations responsible for climate change-related impacts.

To learn more about Hilda's work follow her @nakabuyehildaflavia

Gender bias in autism research and diagnosis is keeping many girls and women from receiving much-needed diagnoses and support. Autism is a neurodevelopment condition that is currently characterized by repetitive and restrictive behaviors, difficulties with social communication, and understanding other people’s intentions. But autistic girls and women are said to have less difficulty processing their emotions and also that of other people, resulting in them not meeting the current diagnostic criteria.

Current autism diagnoses must include more inclusive research that takes girls, trans and nonbinary individuals, and their unique needs and communication into account. Everyone deserves fair access to diagnosis and medical care!

When 18-year-old Kiran from Lucknow, India, realized that many girls and women in her community had no safe spaces to discuss menstruation, she quickly acted to build a peer support group. Most of the participants in the group were unaware of safe menstrual hygiene practices and were often using fabrics that caused them health issues. Kiran started a fund where she and the 20 members of the group would each drop 5 rupees a week to go towards their collective menstrual pad needs.

Kiran shares that this helped the group financially, taught them safe menstrual hygiene practices, and created an emotional support system to fight period poverty and taboo. "This is a small initiative," she says, "But I would like to scale it and create awareness among the people of my village to do the same so that they can invest in their health."

Kiran is a part of our partner organization Milaan Foundation's Girl Icon program. The program selects young women across India and provides them with the resources to create grassroots-level change in their community. To learn more about the inspiring work that the Milaan Foundation (@milaan_foundation) does please visit milaanfoundation.org

Two young high school students in New Orleans discovered a new way to prove a 2,000-year old mathmatics theory. Calcea Johnson and Ne'Kiya Jackson found a way to prove the Pythagorean Theorem using trigonometry without circular logic and presented it at American Mathematical Society's Annual Southeastern Conference where they were the only high school students in the room.

Calcea shared her experience in solving this puzzle, "It's really an unparalleled feeling, honestly, because there's just nothing like being able to do something that people don't think young people can do. A lot of times you see this stuff, you don't see kids like us doing it."

Kudos Calcea and Ne'Kiya for showing the world that you can never be too young to change the way the world works!

Photo: WWLTV

Girls are envisioning a world filled with possibilities that they can bring to life. They just need us to listen and remove the barriers in their way. Join us in building a world where all girls can learn, rise and thrive.

Millions of people around the world have to become activists just to fight for basic rights they should have from birth. Climate injustice is a serious problem caused by rich, industrialized countries that harms marginalized communities across the globe. It affects their access to clean air, drinking water, healthcare, education, and other essential rights.

Follow @nakabuyehildaflavia to learn more about the impact that climate change is having in Uganda and how she is working on combating it.

Last April, the World Health Organization warned of the escalating health risks due to the climate crisis, as 99% of people worldwide breathe unhealthy air. A year later, global emissions remain largely unchanged, and in many countries the situation has worsened. The increasing frequency of extreme weather events further underscores the urgency of addressing the climate crisis. Now more than ever, it's crucial to treat the climate crisis as a global public health emergency.

This World Health Day, let's hold world leaders accountable for immediate action on reducing global emissions. Share this post to raise awareness about this critical issue. #WorldHealthDay #ClimateCrisis #ActNow

Girl Rising is honored to introduce the Natasha Stevens Legacy Fund in honor of one of our dear Girl Rising Champions Dr. Nastasha Stevens. Each year Girl Rising will provide a stipend of $500 USD to a student and/or student group looking to raise awareness in their communities about the power of girls’ education. This year's deadline is Friday, April 21st.

Dr. Natasha Stevens was a fierce champion for girls’ education and a beloved member of the Girl Rising community. She was an inaugural Girl Rising ambassador, organized events in her community and worked tirelessly to support our mission. Natasha tragically passed away in 2022. Through the Natasha Stevens Legacy Fund, Natasha’s passion lives on and will support the efforts of young advocates working to create a world where all girls can learn, rise and thrive. To learn more about this fund click on the link in our bio.

"You can’t have climate justice without gender equality" are the famous words from Vanessa Nakate's speech to the UN Women delegates last March. Vanessa is a Ugandan powerhouse youth climate activist, who started out as a lone protester outside the gates of the Parliament of Uganda striking against inaction on the climate crisis. She is now one of the most critical voices in climate advocacy. As others began to follow her lead, Vanessa founded the Africa-based Rise Up Movement (@riseupmovement1) which brings attention to how climate change disproportionately affects women and girls in Africa.

Vanessa made global headlines in 2020, as she attended a climate conference alongside numerous young climate justice changemakers, including Greta Thunberg, but was cropped out of media coverage which opted to highlight several white activists instead. Since then, she has been battling for diversity and representation in environmental activism and sparked an international conversation on the necessity for tackling environmental racism. To learn more about Vanessa's work follow her @vanessanakate1

Photo: REUTERS / Alamy

Could the key to tackling climate change lie in blending ancient wisdom with modern technology? Future Rising Fellow from Ecuador Leticia Tituana thinks so.

Through her nonprofit, Warmi STEM, Leticia, is determined to amplify the power of Indigenous 
wisdom that has been passed down for generations by supporting young Indigenous women in careers in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM). Warmi STEM's members span across many different regions and Indigenous communities of Ecuador. Their shared objective is to show students in rural communities the possibilities that arise with a career in STEM.

Leticia contends that Indigenous women possess untapped climate change solutions yet to be discovered by researchers and leaders. By combining ancient wisdom on nurturing plants, soil, water, insects, and animals with modern sustainable technology, Leticia believes we can reverse much of the Earth's existing damage.

Learn more about Leticia's innovative ideas and the inspiring work of Warmi STEM @warmi_stem

Photo Credit: Warmi STEM

Climate change is the most significant challenge facing our future, and immediate action is necessary to protect lives worldwide. Girls and women are particularly vulnerable to severe consequences, including gender-based violence, loss of educational opportunities, and exacerbated gender inequalities as climate-related disasters intensify. As we celebrate the Earth this month, let's raise awareness of the crucial connections between climate change and gender inequity.

When the pandemic hit Gayatri Devi knew that the girls in Patna, a city in Eastern India would be the most impacted. Girls in that region experience high rates of being withheld from school and forced marriages. The pandemic has increased the occurrences of this in the community and we are only just exploring the impact of it on girls and women in the city.

Gayatri — who is a facilitator with our partner organization Pragati Gramin Vikas Samiti — is combatting this crisis, armed with Girl Rising’s 16-week social-emotional learning curriculum. She helped adolescent girls in her community tackle complex social-emotional issues using the Girl Rising films and curriculum. “The girls I taught are more like my younger sisters,” she says, “I have formed lifelong friendships with them.”

Gayatri is determined to help as many girls as she can find their voice and agency to self-advocate for their rights. “I can’t bring myself to accept that some individuals are held back from participating in the society and living their life because of their gender,” she says, “We’ve been holding back girls for so long, I have to do my bit to set them free.”

At Girl Rising we know that prioritizing the earth’s well-being and sustainability begins with uplifting historically marginalized communities and groups that are historically disenfranchised including Indigenous women. That’s why we’re so proud to have Future Rising Fellow Raini Sydney from Kenya on our team. Raini has been a vocal advocate for preserving unique, ancient climate-saving wisdom that Indigenous women possess.

Growing up he saw his grandmother till, plant, spray, and harvest wheat and maize sustainably with minimal harm to the environment and without any machinery. He’s now dedicated to preserving the ancient wisdom of Indigenous women and bringing environmentally-friendly practices to food production.

Raini’s Future Rising project is a powerful documentary that tells the stories of female rural smallholder farmers who use natural solutions to fight climate change and build climate-resilient agricultural practices. Follow Raini on his journey by checking out his work on @orsydney. Join us in supporting Raini and our commitment to uplifting marginalized communities for a more just and sustainable future.

#FutureRisingFellow #IndigenousWisdom #ClimateAction #sustainability

Climate change is having devastating impacts on people all around the world, with droughts leading to food scarcity and famines in many regions. But in the face of these challenges, our Future Rising Fellow from Kenya, Mercy Kamonjo, is taking action with the Kuza Generation Initiative.

Mercy was inspired to start this youth-led nonprofit after witnessing the food scarcity caused by extreme dry weather in Kenya. Through Kuza Generation, women and girls are trained in resilient climate-smart agriculture techniques like vertical gardening, sack gardening, and recycling waste materials for farming.

Mercy's leadership has taken her to world stages, including recent speeches at the United Nations Commission on the Status of Women 67 and the United Nations Water Conference. She's been urging global leaders to pay attention to how their actions are impacting marginalized communities like women and girls the most.

Join us in supporting Mercy and the Kuza Generation Initiative as we work towards a more just and sustainable future for all. Follow her journey and learn more about the work of our Future Rising Fellows on our website. #FutureRisingFellow #ClimateAction #Sustainability #YouthLeadership #ClimateSmartAgriculture
To learn more about Mercy's work follow her @kamonjo_mercy

This month, Earth Month, we are proud to showcase the voices and art of the Girl Rising Student Ambassadors. “Prioritizing climate change means we can breathe freely,” exclaims Student Ambassador Maria Bendo (@maria.bendo). Maria, a 4th-year law student in Albania created this digital artwork in honor of Earth Month to illustrate that our everyday choices like supporting big industries that cause air and water pollution, using single-use plastic, and other practices that are increasing global emissions are trapping us in so much trouble that will not have a solution later if we do not act right now.

In the image, Maria depicts the two potential futures that are possible based on our choices. In the top half, we see a world where a girl is breathing freely and living in harmony with nature but in the bottom half you see a girl trapped by the corporate choices that harmed her world.

"The environmental crisis is really a crisis of conscience," she says, "We cannot trash the planet, destroy its biodiversity, alter the climate, and continue living off the wealth of future generations."

Maria's art is part of a recent call to action for Student Ambassadors to demonstrate solutions for protecting the earth through creative art pieces that move people to action. Stay close to @girlrising for more inspiring works like Maria's.

Don't forget to apply for the Natasaha Stevens Legacy Fund! The application deadline closes on April 21st.

Girl Rising will select a student and/or student group and award $500 to help them in their efforts to raise awareness in their communities about the power of girls’ education. Click on the link in our bio to learn more.

In this moving poem, Student Ambassador Priyanka Malla (@priyankamalla712) talks about the one-sided relationship that humanity has with the Earth. Despite the abundance the Earth gives humanity, we continue to exhaust its natural resources and impact its well-being from future generations. Priyanka, who is currently working on her Masters in Public Health in India urges the world to take these steps to protect the earth:

✅ Reduce our carbon footprint: Opt for clean energy sources.
✅Conserve natural resources: Reduce waste, recycle, and use eco-friendly products.
✅Protect biodiversity: We should protect natural habitats, conserve endangered species, and promote sustainable land use to maintain biodiversity.
✅Foster a culture of sustainability by means of accessible, available, and affordable sustainability practices
✅Support and follow policies for conservation of natural resources.

Priyanka's poem is part of a recent call to action for Student Ambassadors to demonstrate solutions for protecting the earth through creative art pieces that move people to action. Follow along on our social this week (@girlrising) for more inspiring works like Priyanka's.

@Barbie We think we have the fiercest crew! What do you think?

Meet some of the Girl Rising team members who are leading change for gender equity and girls' education across the world. To learn more about our work that is challenging gender norms and helping remove barriers in the way of girls' education visit the us at girlrsing.org

Are you an educator looking for engaging ways social justice and gender equity themes into your classroom? Click on the link in our bio for our Educator Newsletter to learn more about how other teachers are incorporating and building upon the Girl Rising curriculum to cultivate important advocacy skills in their students to help build a better future.

Girl Rising CEO Christina Lowery, Future Rising Executive Director and Producer Anna Hall, and Global Program Manager Richa Hingorani had an extraordinary visit with our program partners in Kenya this month. The meetings with partners, educators and young people challenged us to think about how to collaborate and support their work in new ways and how to deepen our educational programming.

Student Ambassador Joy Kalu (@joyikalu) from Nigeria depicts how everyone must care about our planet to heal it. From using energy generated from solar panels to planting flowers and trees, it all plays a part in protecting our planet.

"Our Earth needs urgent attention," Joy says, "This is the only planet that has all humans need to continue living. Therefore we need to give if a priority by making it sustainable."

Meet 11-year-old Licypriya Kangujam (@LicypriyaK), India’s youngest climate activist! In 2019, at just eight years old Licpriya protested outside of the Indian Parliament House to draw the attention of Prime Minister Narendra Modi and to urge him to pass a climate change law in India that would address the air pollution issue.

Since then, Licpriya has bravely called out world leaders by name to take serious actions that impact climate change. She has spoken at nine UN events, including 2019's UN Climate Change Conference COP25. She also founded the Child Movement, an organization that champions every child in the fight against the climate crisis.

“Many people told me that I’m too young to get involved in such activism, but … I strongly believe that children can lead the change,” Licypriya said., “We need to keep speaking up about the climate crisis and … to hold lawmakers accountable for their political decisions.”

Photo: Licypriya Kangujam

Future Rising Fellow Geela Garcia, The Philippines, sheds light on the impact of climate change on the Ivatan community in Batanes, a remote province located in the northernmost island of the Philippines. Through her Future Rising project, Geela chronicles the traditional farming practices of Ivatan women, showcasing their resilience and adaptability despite the challenges they face. Did you know that the Ivatan people are known for their unique architecture, characterized by stone houses that can withstand typhoons? Follow @geelagarcia to discover more about her inspiring work.

📣 Calling all Student Ambassadors! 📣

Join us on May 9th for our Quarterly Student Ambassador virtual event. The event will feature our Future Rising Fellow, Advisory Council Member and Graphic Artist from Nigeria Ayomide Solanke, who will conduct a creative and educational session on how she uses art to create social change in issues such as gender equity and climate justice. Click on the link in our bio to learn more and RSVP.

Earlier this year, Girl Rising launched a campaign in English and Spanish urging fathers to prioritize and fight for their daughters' right to education. The initiative was started by our Guatemala team in response to a concerning drop in girls' school enrollment in Sololá, Guatemala. The campaign inspired male allies in the community to support girls' education. Recently, parents and community members collaborated with our partners REDMI to discuss ways to ensure more girls have access to education in Guatemala. They used Girl Rising tool kits to drive conversations around equal access, combating stereotypes, and supporting daughters to reach their full potential. These community training sessions are crucial in removing barriers to girls' education and empowering advocates for change.

Looking for a unique way to honor the mothers in your life this Mother’s Day? Look no further than our collaboration with digital illustrator and intersectional environmental activist Burcu Koleli (@burcukoleli)! Burcu has created two custom digital art pieces exclusively for Girl Rising, available for just $25 as e-cards that benefit girls in our global programming.

Not only will you be gifting your loved ones with beautiful artwork, but you’ll also be supporting girls’ education around the world, as all proceeds go towards Girl Rising’s work to remove barriers to education. Burcu’s stunning illustrations have been commissioned by renowned organizations such as Nike, UN Women, and Planned Parenthood, and now you can bring her unique style into your own home.

Give your mother the gift of giving back this Mother’s Day by clicking on the link in our bio to learn more and view the captivating art pieces. Show the mothers in your life how much you care, while also making a difference in the lives of girls everywhere.

Corporate partners are essential in making Girl Rising’s vision of a world where all girls learn, rise, and thrive a reality! We are excited and grateful to join forces with Room to Read (@roomtoread), Plan International (@planinternational), Teach for All (@teachforall), and Aflatoun International (@aflatoun_international) as non-profit partners in Credit Suisse’s Financial Education Initiative (creditsuisse_ch). Through this collaboration, we’ve launched our newest programs in Ghana and Mexico, positively impacting adolescent girls in each country this year.

Our partnership with Credit Suisse also opens doors to other opportunities to collaborate. Recently our Future Rising Fellows, Lety Tituanafrom, Ecuador, and Hilda Flavia Nakabuye from Uganda had the opportunity to meet with Credit Suisse employees in person in New York City, sharing the advocacy and environmental work they are advancing in their communities to combat climate change. Follow lety_tp and @nakabuyehildaflavia to learn more about climate change’s impact in Ecuador and Uganda and how they are leading change.

Looking for a source of inspiration that lands straight in your inbox? Look no further than The Rise, Girl Rising's monthly newsletter. Featuring stories of changemakers from our programming and global community, The Rise offers exclusive stories and behind-the-scenes features that focus on the transformative power of education. Sign up now to receive your monthly dose of thought-provoking content and beautiful photography. Join our community of change-makers and sign up for The Rise today!

Click on the link in our bio to read our most recent newsletter and subscribe to stay connected.

It takes all of us to protect the planet. But women are too often left out of critical climate decision-making rooms.

It's time to change that! According to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change, national-level environmental governing bodies rarely achieve gender parity, and women make up only one-third of environmental ministry employees on average. But we need more women at the table to protect our planet and ensure a sustainable future for all. Join us in advocating for gender parity in environmental leadership and working towards a more equitable and just world. Because it takes all of us to protect the planet.

#FutureRising #GenderEquality #ClimateAction #Sustainability

text_entities.entity: united nations framework convention on climate change

social_posts.post_text:
Still searching for the perfect Mother’s Day gift? Look no further! Our collaboration with digital illustrator and intersectional environmental activist Burcu Koleli (@burcukoleli) is sure to please! For just $25, you can send the mother in your life a custom digital art piece that’s not only beautiful but also supports girls’ education worldwide through Girl Rising’s global programming.

With Burcu’s beautiful illustrations, commissioned by organizations like Nike, UN Women, and Planned Parenthood, you can bring her unique style into your own home and make a difference in the world. Every purchase helps to remove barriers to education and empowers girls to reach their full potential.

So why not give the mothers in your life the gift of giving back this Mother’s Day? Click on the link in our bio to learn more and view the captivating art pieces. Don’t miss your chance to make a meaningful impact and spread love this holiday season.

#MothersDay #GiftsWithMeaning #GirlRising

Girls in our Financial Education Initiative programming in Mexico are learning critical skills to take control of their financial futures. By exploring their goals and dreams, they're discovering how to differentiate between financial wants and needs and prioritize their spending accordingly. These skills are essential for breaking the cycle of poverty and creating a more equitable world.

Through our programming, we're providing girls with the resources and knowledge they need to make informed financial decisions and achieve financial stability. Join us in supporting girls' education and help build a brighter future for all.

#GirlsEducation #FinancialLiteracy #BreakingTheCycle

When Jaha Dukureh became a mother, she knew she could no longer sit on the sidelines around issues she cared about. As a Gambian women's right activist and anti-female genital mutilation (FGM) campaigner, she knew it was her responsibility to speak out for her daughter and for every marginalized community that was being silenced.

"We all have a moral obligation to ensure that violence against women ends," she says "We can do this through advocacy. We can do this through individual work. We cannot stay silent."

Jaha brought her communities together by sharing her own experiences in early, forced marriage and FGM; subsequently founding Safe Hands for Girls, an organization working to end FGM. She has dedicated her career to girls and young women as she focuses on mobilizing youth and empowering daughters globally.

Jaha proves that despite many stereotypes about motherhood being a barrier, it is often the catalyst for creating powerful change.  Mothers change the trajectory of the next generation of our societies, as they help their daughters find their agency and voice, teach their sons to value their girls; education, and redefine themselves as changemakers.

Photo: Jaha Dukureh

In her thought-provoking film, Future Rising Fellow Beverley Choo (@beverleychoo) from Singapore tells the story of the Dayak people, an Indigenous community in Indonesia, as they struggle to navigate the effects of climate change on their environment. Climate change compounds the difficulties faced by Indigenous communities like the Dayak people by exasperating economic and political marginalization, loss of land and resources, and by increasing human rights violations, discrimination, and unemployment.

The Dayak people rely on swidden agriculture and supplement their income by collecting forest products such as ferns, medicinal plants, fibers, and timber for subsistence and sale. However, modernization and climate change have caused significant deforestation, leaving the community in dire straits. It is our responsibility to implement inclusive practices that protect the rights of Indigenous peoples and ensure they are not left behind in the fight against climate change.

Sophie Cruz was only five years old when she made international headlines for  hand-delivering a letter to Pope Francis asking him to protect her parents who are undocumented immigrants in the United States.

“Pope Francis, I want to tell you that my heart is very sad, because I’m scared that one day ICE (U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement) is going to deport my parents," she wrote. "I have a right to live with my parents. I have a right to be happy.  Immigrants like my dad feed this country. They therefore deserve to live with dignity, they deserve to be respected, they deserve immigration reform."

Since then Sophie has spoken at the White House, to the Supreme Court, and the annual Women's March.

Girls across the world are challenging norms and ushering in a new era of reform, inclusive policies, stronger families, and sustainable communities. As we celebrate International Day of Families, we all need to recognize the valuable contributions of girls in generational healing and uplifting of family units. Let's commit to listening to them and removing barriers in their way. Click on the link in our bio to learn how you can join the movement to support girls.

Introducing Catalina Chacon, the new Future Rising Program Manager at Girl Rising!

Catalina brings a wealth of experience in mental health, grassroots development, and education to Girl Rising. For over a decade, she has been dedicated to creating a more just world for women and girls in Central America. Growing up with immigrant parents in Los Angeles, California, and later residing in Costa Rica, Catalina deeply appreciates the significance of generational transformation and is steadfast in her commitment to forging a brighter future for all. While her journey began in environmental activism, she discovered her true passion for youth development, which led her to co-found the Sirenitas Surf Club in Nicaragua—an inclusive community space where girls explore their power through surfing, swimming, and education. Through her work, Catalina aspires to foster a world where girls can dare to dream big and, most importantly, possess the tools necessary to achieve those dreams.

Catalina holds a Bachelor's degree in Psychology from Universidad Centroamericana de Ciencias Sociales and a Master's degree in Gender and Peacebuilding from the University for Peace. Additionally, she is certified in art therapy by the Universidad Nacional Autónoma de México. Beyond her professional pursuits, Catalina is a loving mother to a spirited 4-year-old girl and dotes on three adoring dogs.

We are thrilled to have Catalina join our team, and we look forward to the incredible impact she will undoubtedly make in advancing our mission. Stay tuned for exciting updates on the Future Rising Program under Catalina's dedicated leadership!

Meet Laetania Belai Djandam (Belai), an Indigenous Dayak Climate Advocate who is at the forefront of protecting the rights and access of the Dayak people. Belai’s climate advocacy strategy is central to safeguarding the Dayak community. Her inspiring journey is beautifully captured in a film by Future Rising Fellow, Beverley Choo (@beverleychoo) from Singapore, which sheds light on the challenges faced by the Dayak people as they navigate the impacts of climate change.

Deforestation not only deprives the Dayak people of their ancestral lands but also disrupts their traditional way of life. This loss of forests translates into a loss of vital resources, livelihoods, and cultural practices deeply connected to nature. It is imperative to acknowledge and honor Indigenous rights, traditional knowledge, and local participation in decision-making processes. By doing so, we can develop effective strategies to mitigate the impact of climate change on the Dayak people and other indigenous communities worldwide.

To delve deeper into the incredible work of our Future Rising program and gain insights into the endeavors of our Fellows, simply click on the link provided in our bio.

Anam brings over six years of experience working in the international development sector, specializing in evidence-based policy-making. Is your period rights advocacy binary? Menstruation is a natural and normal bodily process that transcends gender. It's time to recognize and respect the diverse identities and experiences of all individuals.

By incorporating gender-inclusive language in period rights advocacy, we foster inclusivity and create a safe space for everyone to discuss and access menstrual health resources. No one should feel excluded or silenced due to their gender identity.

Join Girl Rising for the next two weeks as we amplify various stories and perspectives of people who menstruate and the challenges they face in honor of Menstrual Hygiene Day. Let's challenge societal norms and create a world where menstrual hygiene is a human right, regardless of gender identity, culture, or socio-economic status.

As silence, shame, and stigma still overshadow the experiences of people who menstruate across the world, Jyoti Rawat from Uttar Pradesh, India refused to accept the stigma surrounding menstruation. With unwavering determination, she embarked on a journey to empower herself and countless others in her community.

Jyoti, who is part of our partner organization Milaan Foundation's Girl Icon program, has been raising awareness about period poverty, dismantling myths, and pushing for inclusive menstrual health education in Uttar Pradesh for over a year. She has been engaging policymakers, and organizations, and community members in discussions about menstrual taboo. She initially experienced a lot of pushback from community members who felt that it was shameful to talk about periods openly. But Jyoti never gave up.

Recently, she gathered her peers and held an awareness event, where they performed a street-play to educate community members on the importance of destigmatizing menstruation.This creative approach to tackling complex issues spoke to many in the community. The event was a smashing success and even those who once opposed her efforts became believers. Inspired by this success, Jyoti is now committed to expanding her advocacy to other villages surrounding her.

Join us in celebrating Jyoti's inspiring story and her relentless pursuit of period rights. Let her courage inspire you to break period taboo and advocate to make menstrual supplies more accessible for all.

In Kenya, Girl Rising facilitators and mentors are building safe spaces to help youth in our programming understand menstruation, combat taboos, and create pathways to tackle the lack of access. Girl Rising’s Kenya Program coordinator Debbie Odenyi is challenging period stigma and helping to create more access to menstrual health management so young people across the world can discuss periods without shame and grow from the power of shared narratives.

As Debbie shows, we all have a role to play in ending the stigma surrounding menstruation! Share this post to spread the word and inspire others to join the movement!

In Mexico and around the world, period taboo continues to hinder progress as few parents feel comfortable talking about menstruation with their children, It perpetuates cycles of fear and anxiety in youth who experience menstruation and often gets in the way of a conducive learning environment.

Follow along as Girl Rising’s Mexico Program Manager Naomi Ramos talks about the specific menstruation-related barriers that youth in Mexico experience and efforts that community members and the world can take to help build spaces for young people to navigate the topic of menstruation comfortably and without shame or stigma.

It's time to break the silence and end the stigma surrounding menstruation. Together, we can create a world where periods are embraced, understood, and celebrated! 🩸✨

Around 25% of the current world population is likely experiencing menstruation, according to UNICEF data, and yet this natural life experience is still shrouded in significant stigma. Period taboo and lack of access is hindering many individuals from fully participating in school, work, and society.

We cannot wait any longer on taking the critical steps needed to dismantle the shame, myths, and misconceptions that hold us back. Let's challenge and empower individuals to have more open discussions surrounding menstruation. And hold world leaders accountable for creating policies that protect period rights and increase access to menstrual supplies.

Despite increased conversation surrounding period stigma and lack of access, young people who menstruate still face overwhelming barriers to finding support and supplies for menstrual health management.

At Girl Rising, we believe that menstrual hygiene education is a fundamental aspect of promoting gender equality and ensuring that all girls can reach their full potential, this is why we are calling for an end to period stigma. We call on parents, world leaders and governments, and individual community members to commit with us to address subconscious biases in our language, policies, and social structures that are promoting period stigma and widening the period poverty gap.

Click on the link in our bio to learn more about the work that members in the Girl Rising community are doing to advocate for menstrual equity.

Have you heard of The Pink Tax? It’s a form of gender-based price discrimination that corporations use to charge more on products marketed for women. This form of discrimination can have devastating impacts on the widening menstrual inequity gap. It’s time to expose this unfair practice and demand change!

Essential menstrual products like pads, tampons, and menstrual cups are often subject to higher prices simply because they are marketed towards women. This discriminatory practice makes it even more difficult for individuals who menstruate to access the products they need.

No one should be penalized or priced out of their right to manage their periods with dignity. It’s time to dismantle the barriers that the Pink Tax imposes on menstrual equity! Share this video to call on government leaders and organizations to dismantle The Pink Tax.

Debbie Odenyi, our Program Manager in Kenya participated as a panelist in Drawing Dreams Initiative's (@drawingdreams_initiative) Menstrual Health Summit in Nanyuki, Laikipia County to highlight partnerships to achieve menstrual equity. She and other event leaders engaged with nearly 150 individuals, ages 5 to 50, to help raise awareness and generate ideas to end menstrual stigma. The team created plans to continue to prioritize the issue with community members, local governments, and private organizations and increase access to menstrual supplies.

"Most summits end in conference rooms or halls,” Debbie says. "But having community engagement gives individuals a first-hand experience of deep learning and listening to the community's needs, particularly youth who menstruate, and having them in mind as they design their programs. We are hopeful that this summit will have lasting impacts in the minds of the attendees and they will create an upward spiral of change in their communities."

Did you know that starting a menstrual cycle means the end of schooling for many adolescents across the world? Widespread menstrual stigma and lack of access is still an insurmountable barrier for many youth but it doesn’t have to be. Combatting the stigma, creating more safe spaces for discussion about menstruation, and creating more access to menstrual health supplies can help keep many young people in school.

Girl Rising’s global programs director Richa Hingorani is urging more individuals to join Girl Rising’s effort to stop letting menstruation be a barrier in the way of education. Share this video to get more people to talk about menstruation and end the stigma!

Period equity starts with ensuring that everyone's narratives are heard and addressed in advocacy efforts. Transgender model Kenny Ethan Jones is amplifying the voices of trans and gender-nonconforming individuals' right to period equity. As a period rights activist, he shares his story of isolation, physical and psychological pain, and gender dysphoria associated with a monthly period. It is easy to feel isolated when menstruation products and education on menstrual health solely focus on girls and women.

Trans men, gender-nonconforming, intersex individuals who menstruate not only face the lack of access to menstruation products and education but safety concerns. The 2015 U.S. Transgender Survey, by the National Center for Transgender Equality, found that nearly 60% of respondents reported being too afraid to use public restrooms due to fear of a confrontation. With an additional 12% reported being verbally harassed while accessing a bathroom in the past year.

Kenny Jones is challenging the stigma around the period experiences of individuals who are not cis women by using his own vulnerability and story. As we celebrate pride month this June, Girl Rising is committed to helping more people's period activism go beyond gender roles.

Photo credit: Gareth Cattermole /Getty Images file, Estrid/Getty

Environmental sustainability and access to education are deeply interconnected. Investing in one strengthens the other.

Extreme weather events, natural disasters, and environmental degradation disrupt all schooling and pose significant barriers to girls' education. By addressing environmental changes and building climate resilience, we open pathways for adolescents to pursue their education without interruptions.

Let's use World Environment Day as an opportunity to advocate for climate-smart education and inclusive climate action.

Did you know that oceans absorb about 30% of all human-generated CO2 emissions? They are our planet’s lungs!

With climate change worsening, sea levels are rising, ocean acidification is increasing, and extreme weather events are becoming more frequent - threatening livelihoods and access to clean water, food security, and education. This disproportionately affects vulnerable communities, with girls and women often facing the brunt of the impacts.

This #WorldOcean Day, let’s stand together to:

🌊 Raise awareness about the critical links between protecting our oceans, climate change, and gender equity.
🌊 Equip girls and women with a quality education and opportunities to be climate change leaders.
🌊 Support initiatives that promote sustainable ocean practices and conservation efforts.
🌊 Advocate for policies that prioritize the rights and resilience of girls and women in climate action.

Oceans not only absorb CO2, but they also act as a crucial regulator of Earth’s temperature, helping to maintain the delicate balance of our planet’s climate systems. That’s why we should all work together to protect our oceans. #WorldOceanDay2023

Source: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration

Children worldwide should be in school on Monday mornings, but instead, millions are toiling away as child laborers. According to the International Labor Organization, there are approximately 152 million children involved in child labor worldwide, with almost half engaged in hazardous work. Childhood moments are stolen, replaced by grueling work and harsh realities.

At Girl Rising, we're collaborating with parents and caregivers around the world, emphasize the importance of prioritizing quality education for young people.

Join us in amplifying our efforts to make education more accessible for adolescents. Together, we can address child labor, ensuring every child has the opportunity to gain an education.

Announcing Nidhi Shukla as Girl Rising's new President! Formerly the Head of Global Programming based in Delhi, India, Shukla will join CEO Christina Lowery in leading Girl Rising in increasing education access for girls and transforming communities around the world. Nidhi's appointment is a continuing strategy to infuse global perspectives into Girl Rising’s leadership and all areas of its work.

A former human rights lawyer, Nidhi brings 20 years of experience in the social justice sector and an unwavering commitment to using the power of storytelling-to drive change. She has been a part of Girl Rising since 2015, when she led the India team in designing and implementing a social action campaign in association with the Girl Rising original documentary.

"I am honored to take on the role of President at Girl Rising and work alongside a talented team of passionate individuals who are committed to transforming the lives of girls and their communities through education," said Nidhi. "I have seen firsthand how Girl Rising’s focus on storytelling to build understanding, forge connections, and create empathy is uniquely effective in breaking down gender barriers - and excited to work alongside CEO Christina Lowery as we move into our second decade of growth and impact."

Huge congratulations to Nidhi(@nidhi2601). To learn more about this appointment and to read about Nidhi's plans to accelerate Girl Rising's mission click on the link in our bio.

Introducing Margarita Jalca, the newest addition to Girl Rising's team as our Finance Assistant!

With over 12 years of accounting and finance experience in diverse industries, Margarita has made her mark in her home country Ecuador, as well as across America and Asia. At Girl Rising we recognize that today's gender equity work must include efforts to bridge the digital divide. According to the World Bank only 60% of the world population has digital access. Girl Rising is working to tackle this issue in partnership with @HP and our program partner in Kenya, Sunflower Trust (@sunflower_global) by bringing computer and Internet access to adolescents in Kibera, an informal settlement in Nairobi.

The girls eagerly engage in their computer lessons and have now developed interest in STEM related careers and many of them have expressed dreams of being web developers and coders. These girls are a testament to the fact that promoting digital literacy, investing in infrastructure, and providing affordable access can unlock immense potential in young people and can have lasting impacts on their communities.

Last week the United Nations Development Programme released a sobering report that indicates that globally we have seen no improvement in biases against women in a decade. This revelation serves as a wake-up call, highlighting the pressing need to amplify our efforts and accelerate our work towards achieving true gender equity. Recently we launched a series of workshops in Pakistan with parents of adolescent girls through our Kaavish project, in partnership with Together Women Rise (@togetherwomenriseorg). Pakistan Program Manager Nasreen Samad and the project team led groups of parents in open discussions about their daughters’ education and opportunities, fostering a stronger partnership between parents, educators and Girl Rising to drive lasting change.

"At Girl Rising, we approach parent engagement with the same level of preparation and dedication as any other significant stakeholder engagement, with extensive research to tailor our workshops to meet the specific needs of the community,” said Nasreen. “I see firsthand, when we foster intentional conversations with parents based on very specific objectives, they show a keen interest and high motivation to participate in our programming for the development of their children”

With the support of our longtime partner @HP, we are expanding our Future Rising program, collaborating with two organizations founded by Future Rising Fellows Julieta Martinez (@julietamartinezo; Chile) and Leticia Tituana (lety_tp; Ecuador).

Girl Rising will partner with Julieta and Leticia to tailor our storytelling curricula to the specific needs of their communities in rural and underserved areas of Ecuador and Chile. This initiative will support adolescent girls as they develop their communication and storytelling skills and express themselves through creative writing and spoken word. Girl Rising will also enhance the digital capacity of both organizations as part of the project and support ‘Tremendas’ (@tremendascl) implementation of a regional survey of 20,000 girls in eight countries in Latin Americas. The findings will be presented at the UN General Assembly in New York in September 2023.

Every year, millions of children are uprooted from their homes, schools, and familiar environments due to natural disasters, conflict, or forced migration. Many are pushed out of structured learning environments they once relied upon and some are deprived of access to any education at all. In the fight for education equity, it is vital that we do not forget the millions of children currently displaced from their homes.

It's our collective responsibility to ensure that every child, regardless of their circumstances, can access quality education and have the opportunity to reach their full potential. Click on the link in our bio to learn more about how you can support Girl Rising's work in education equity.

Education is the transformative force for freedom for many women and girls across the world. A quality education empowers them to make informed choices,  gives them the resources to pursue their passions, and helps them break free from the cycles of inequality and discrimination.

Girl Rising's programming helps girls develop voice and agency to advocate for their right to education. We also work with parents, community members and policymakers to remove barriers in the way of girls' education. Click on the link in our bio to learn more about Girl Rising's work.

"I am determined to bring gender equality to Bangladesh. I believe in the power of women and girls to fight for our rights. We will succeed.”

Meet Rima Sultana Rimu, a remarkable woman from a farming family in the Chittagong Division of Bangladesh. Even in her early years, Rima recognized the transformative power of education and its potential to uplift her community. Today, she is celebrated globally as an advocate for gender-responsive humanitarian action and a passionate champion of women's rights in Bangladesh.

Rima's influential work has garnered international recognition, particularly for her efforts in providing education resources to women and children residing in Rohingya refugee camps. She collaborates closely with the UN Security Council to promote education on women, peace, and security. Rima's unique approach incorporates storytelling as a powerful tool, utilizing radio broadcasts, captivating theater performances, and more traditional classroom teaching methods.

Driven by her deep-rooted commitment to her community, Rima tirelessly strives to make education more accessible to the next generation of girls in Bangladesh. Her dedication and compassion continue to make a lasting impact, empowering young minds and shaping a brighter future for all.

Learn more about Rima's work she does by following the link in our bio.

Photo: UN Women/Mahmudul Karim

Discover the story of Paz Quevedo, an eco-feminist and activist from Cabrero, Chile, who is courageously fighting against industrial pollution and mono-cultivation, which threaten her community and the surrounding ecosystem.

Paz's journey is part of the Future Rising project led by 20-year-old Julieta Martinez (@julietamartinezo) from Chile. Through her nonprofit organization, Tremendas (@tremendascl), which she founded at the age of 14, Julieta provides climate education, networking and advocacy work to young people throughout Latin America. This climate education academy has empowered Paz and others like her to make a difference. Tremendas now operates in 18 countries across Latin America and the Caribbean, uniting nearly 2000 girls between the ages of 12 and 25.

To watch Julieta's film Las Nubes de Paz, click on the link in our bio. Join us in celebrating the courage and determination of young leaders who are working towards a better future for their communities.

Introducing Dania, a college student who is using the power of social media to encourage girls to develop financial literacy skills. Dania’s story is an integral part of our Credit Suisse Financial Education Initiative programs in Mexico and Ghana, which aim to equip adolescents with essential financial and life skills that will shape their futures, both professionally and personally.

Dania's fascination with hairstyling began at a young age while watching her mother cut and braid hair. Now, she's on her way to becoming a successful beauty entrepreneur herself.

Dania has some invaluable advice for young girls: "Don't wait until you have a lot of money to invest in a business. I started with a little, and now I've multiplied it by five. Take a risk and always pursue what you love."

Together with local partners CIAM and Glasswing (Mexico); Dels Foundation and The Exploratory (Ghana), and Aflatoun, we've developed our most comprehensive program to date, focusing on financial literacy, voice, agency, goal setting, and gender equality. Join us in shaping a better future for thousands of adolescents. Discover more about our initiative by clicking the link in our bio.

Our global population is approaching 8 billion individuals. This should mean 8 billion opportunities for quality primary and secondary education. Yet despite progress in education rights, 773 million adults cannot read or write, and millions of children are not in school.

As we recognize World Population Day let's not forget that barriers such as discrimination, conflict, poverty, and the climate crisis still prevent millions from completing their education and fulfilling their potential. When we prioritize education, we pave the way for a more equitable and prosperous world. Spread the word, raise awareness, and support organizations working towards education equity - and join us in advocating for a world where 100% of the world's population has access to education.

Click on this link in our bio to learn about how you can get involved with Girl Rising today.

Today we celebrate the remarkable courage and leadership Malala Yousafzai on International Malala Day, first marked on her 16th birtday in 2013 when she made her first speech at the United Nations in New York City.

Malala’s journey from student, to education activist, to international leader serves as a powerful testament that even in the face of violent opposition, the voices of girls can spark a revolution and inspire change. Her fight for the right to education ignited a global movement, shedding light on the tremendous barriers girls face in the pursuit of their right to an education.

Today, as we pay tribute to @malala and honor activists championing gender and education rights worldwide, we deepen our commitment to amplify the voices of girls, dismantle barriers, and create pathways for increased access to education. Together, we can create a world where every girl can learn, rise, and thrive.

Click on the link in our bio to see how you can support Girl Rising’s work to make education equity a reality for all.

Girls are one of the world's most powerful forces for positive change. When you equip them with education the possibilities are endless. 🌍✨

Join Girl Rising in removing barriers in the way of girls globally. Click on the link in our bio to learn how you can get involved.

Small ideas can have a big impact.

At just 4 years old, a bee sting sparked Mikaila Ulmer's (@mikailasbees) curiosity instead of fear. Intrigued by the importance of bees as pollinators and their alarming decline, she took action. By the age of 11, she had built a lemonade empire in Texas, all in an effort to save the honeybees.

Using her great-grandmother's lemonade recipe, Mikaila added her own twist of honey from the honeybees, creating her company, Me & the Bees Lemonade. In 2015, she showcased her social entrepreneurial skills on Shark Tank, where entrepreneurs pitch their ideas to investors. Mikaila impressed the panel and secured a $60,000 investment, garnering even more support for her growing business.

Every day, Mikaila's business continues to flourish, serving as an inspiration for aspiring entrepreneurs, especially young girls. Her journey proves that age is not a barrier to achieving remarkable accomplishments. She has become a role model, showcasing the power of determination and the potential to make a difference.

Mikaila Ulmer's story is a shining example of how one person can create positive change, starting with a simple idea and a lot of passion. Let's celebrate her entrepreneurial spirit and be inspired to follow our own dreams, no matter our age or circumstances.

Photo: Rodolfo Gonzalez/Austin American-Statesman via AP

Last week, we introduced you to Dania, a budding Mexican hair stylist, entrepreneur, and influencer, in a new short film. Now, Dania is taking her experiences beyond the screen and into the real world as she visited young people in Girl Rising programming in Mexico to share her personal experiences and encouraged them to also prioritize financial literacy.

In a rapidly evolving world, equipping young girls with not just classroom education but also financial literacy and practical skills is essential.

"Believing in oneself is crucial to feeling driven towards a goal. However, it is not sufficient alone." Dania explained, "Achieving a goal demands effort, discipline, organization, confronting fears, and having a clear vision of what you want. Only then can you reap the rewards of your endeavors, which is ultimately what we all desire."

This World Youth Skills Day, take some time to click on the link in our bio to explore Girl Rising's Financial Education Initiative, implemented in partnership with Credit Suisse in Mexico and Ghana. The initiative helps equip thousands of adolescents with essential financial and life skills that will help them shape successful futures.

Did you know that educating girls has a profound impact on the global economy? An educated girl is likely to increase her personal earning potential and as a result pull her family and community in an upward financial trajectory.

The World Bank reports that it is costing countries between $15 trillion to $30 trillion in untapped earning potential when girls are deprived of the opportunity to complete 12 years of education. Building stronger global economies has to start with investing in girls.

Click on the link in our bio to see how you can join Girl Rising in investing in girls for a better future for all of us.

On this day, we commemorate Nelson Mandela's legacy and his unwavering dedication to education's transformative power. From his early years in segregated South Africa, Mandela witnessed the unequal access to education faced by his Black peers. He recognized that education holds the key to breaking the chains of inequality, opening doors to a brighter future. Even during his imprisonment for opposing apartheid, Mandela pursued a law degree to advocate for equal rights, including the right to quality education.

Upon his release, Mandela wasted no time translating his advocacy into action through his nonprofit, Schools for Africa. This organization continues his mission by promoting quality education in 13 African countries.

Today, let us honor Mandela's legacy by championing education rights. Together, we can ensure that every child has the opportunity to unleash their full potential. Click the link in our bio to learn how you can make a difference.

In Embu County, Kenya, the government created a dump site as a​ short-term response to the region’s increasing population and increasing waste. But years later the dump has only grown in size, causing detrimental impacts on the local environment and health of the residents.

Dump sites like this are becoming common place in the most marginalized regions of the world In 2019, the US exported more than 1 billion pounds of plastic waste to 96 countries, including Kenya.

In this powerful film Future Rising Fellow, Kenya, @calton_nthama tells the story of one family whose life is impacted by the dump site and the work of local residents to advocate for better conditions. Click on the link in our bio to watch the film now.

A crayon color for everyone!

When Bellen Woodard (@morethanpeachproject) was in the third grade she was asked to retrieve a “skin colored crayon” and while she reached for the peach colored crayon she thought about how her own skin color did not match the peach. From that day on she proclaimed herself to be a Crayon Activist and started the More Than A Peach project.

Bellen’s mission is to get crayons that represent all children and to change the way people think about skin color. She is making the world more inclusive, one crayon at a time. She began by creating a dialogue in her classroom and changing the language the students speak to each other about their own and others' skin tone. She then expanded it to create crayon activism movement across her small community in Virginia and into her state at large. And now with her mother's help, she started a business selling these inclusive boxes of crayons all across the globe!

Bellen’s crayon packs recently made history as they have recently been added to the Virginian Museum of History and Culture. We applaud Bellen and her family as they help create a more inclusive world.

Photo courtesy: Tosha Woodard
