Storytelling, an essential 21st century skill, has the power to ignite action and shed light on social challenges and innovative solutions. At Girl Rising, a key part of our work is to build storytelling skills among young people who are determined to address climate change and pave the way for a just and sustainable future.

Last month Future Rising Senior Fellow, Lauren Ritchie (@laurenaritchie) co-led See My Island, a free two-week creative storytelling and climate action camp in The Bahamas, engaging girls aged 11-16.

During the camp, the 16 girls from Eleuthera and Nassau explored their local marine ecosystems and examined the profound impacts of climate change. Through poetry, photography, videography, and art, they crafted narratives that beautifully and creatively told the story of their home, their heritage, and their roles as environmental stewards.

This immersive experience not only honed their storytelling skills but also fostered a deep connection to their environment and instilled a sense of responsibility for its protection. These young changemakers are amplifying their voices and using their creative talents to raise awareness about the urgent need for climate action.

Did you know that some of the most potent climate solutions are hidden in mangroves across the world?

These remarkable ecosystems play a crucial role in mitigating climate change impacts, from absorbing carbon dioxide to acting as natural barriers against erosion, storms, and hurricanes. They also provide livelihood opportunities for millions of people. However, climate change, pollution, and overexploitation put their survival at risk.

Join our Future Rising Fellow, Astrid Peraza (@astridprzj) from Costa Rica, as she explores the natural wonders of mangroves and shares the inspiring story of a fishing community’s fight to preserve the mangroves in their region. Follow our social media for announcements on the release of this film in the end of August.

Since history has been recorded, women have taken on unofficial roles as conservationists as they act as stewards of land, securers of food and water, and caretakers or animals. Yet, men still overwhelmingly influence current environmental and conservation decisions, according to the International Union for Conservation of Nature.

These five inspiring Kenyan conservationists are not letting the odds stop them, instead they are shattering gender barriers to protect our natural resources. This World Conservation Day, join us in celebrating these powerful changemakers! Learn more about them by clicking on the link in our bio.

✨ Happy International Day of Friendship! ✨

A growing body of research indicates that friendships can positively impact school performance for girls. Researchers Youjin Hahn, Asadul Islam, Eleonora Patacchini, and Yves Zenou collected data on academic performance of girls in 115 primary schools in Pakistan and concluded that girls who had friiends and studied in groups outperformed their counterparts who did not have a strong support system.

This validates what a lot of us already knew, meaningful friendships can uplift and motivate us to excel and pursue our passions fearlessly. Tag your besties in the comments and thank them for being your unwavering support system.

Click on the link in our bio to read article!

In 2013 we told you the story of Suma, a brave young woman in Nepal who overcame the Kamlari system to get educated herself and advocate for educations rights of chilldren all over Nepal. The Kamlari system is a centuries-old practice in Nepal, where young girls, often from disadvantaged backgrounds, are sent to work as domestic servants.

Despite Suma breaking out of the system and the Nepalese government outlawing it, the Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights believes that there likely are still hundreds of children in Nepal who are bonded laborers.

Estimates indicate that a staggering 1.2 million children are trafficked each year. These innocent children face extreme hardships, denied education, and subjected to various forms of abuse, including physical, emotional, and sexual violence. Trapped in a cycle of exploitation, they suffer in silence, their dreams and potential shattered.

This World Day against Trafficking in Persons we encourage you to write to your government leaders and urge for more policies that protect individuals, especially children, from trafficking. Together, we must work towards a work where human trafficking has no place!

Barbie Breaks Records! 🎉 Cheers to Greta Gerwig and the amazing cast and crew of the "Barbie" movie for smashing opening week records! 🎬💪 "Barbie" is now officially the top-grossing movie directed by a woman in its first weekend! 👏

This fantastic achievement goes beyond just breaking records - it's a big win for gender representation and equity! 🌟 The movie fearlessly dives into the everyday challenges faced by women and girls in a fun, refreshing, and empowering way that only Barbie can pull off! 💖

It's incredible to see people of all genders embracing the pink and engaging in thought-provoking conversations about gender-related issues because of this film! 🌈✨ This is a proud moment for gender advocates everywhere! Let's celebrate the power of cinema to spark meaningful change! 🙌

If you haven't watched it yet, don't miss out on the fun! We totally recommend you catch "Barbie" on the big screen! 🎉🍿 🌸✨💅🏻👛

Last month we showed you the sobering findings from the United Nations Development Programme Gender Social Norms Index (GSNI) which reveals 9 out of 10 men and women hold fundamental biases against women.  Girl Rising CEO Christina Lowery and President Nidhi Shukla share their views on why biases against girls and women are so deeply entrenched, what these findings mean for the fight for girls' education rights, and tangible steps that individuals can take to combat pervasive gender bias in their own communities.

At Girl Rising, we will continue to dig in to the GSNI data, as well as other new research and findings such as the new UNDP Women's Empowerment Index to help advance rights for girls and women around the globe.  We invite you to join the conversation.

Education in Pakistan has faced significant challenges due to the COVID-19 pandemic, devastating floods, and gender bias issues. To tackle this, we launched the Kaavish project in partnership with Together Women Rise.

In the most impacted areas, we’re providing adolescents, educators, parents, and community members with the resources, training, and skills to advocate for equitable, quality education. The response has been incredible! Parents and community members are embracing tangible skills to support girls in overcoming gender inequality and accessing education.

Join us in celebrating the strong girls and their allies who are making a real difference in their communities through the Kaavish project. Together, we’re creating a brighter future with education for all.

At See My Island, a collaboration among Future Rising, The Island School and the Sean Connery Foundation, Girl Rising brought together a group of Bahamian girls for an immersive climate change action and storytelling camp. Over the two weeks the campers, ages 11-16, participated in workshops with local marine scientists, activists, and artists, on a deep exploration of their local ecosystems and their own unique personal stories - creating poetry, films, photo presentations, and sculptures from recycled materials.

These young leaders are using their creations to raise awareness about the impacts of climate change on their communities and around the world.

Recently, our Kenya Program Manager Debbie Odenyi represented Girl Rising at the Women Deliver conference in Kigali, where 6,000 gender equity advocates and 200,000+ online supporters came together to catalyze collective action to advance gender equality. The event featured powerhouse speakers such as Nobel Laureate Malala Yousafzai, Executive Director Dr. Sima Bahous, President of The Republic of Rwanda H.E. Paul Kagame, President of Senegal H.E. Macky Sall and Political Leader Stacey Abrams. 

Girl Rising was a part of a community of notable nonprofit organizations, such as Echidna Giving, Population Council, Save the Children, Malala Fund, Amplify Girls, Girl Up, Ecobank Foundation, and GPE, collaborating to tackle current humanitarian crises impacting girls and women. The Women Deliver community has been engaging in a global dialogue for six months leading up to the conference and will continue to hold leaders accountable and create spaces for girls and women globally.

"It is important for organizations not to work in silos," says Debbie, "Challenges in the education for girls are colossal and there is a dire need for a concerted effort from organizations in eradicating them. It is critical that we collectively work with young girls on their own self-awareness, mental health, and mindfulness so they are able to transcend traditional gender norms while setting goals for themselves believe in their strengths, and are able to make informed decisions."

A huge thank you to the talented lineup of artists and activists, Tanicia Pratt, Shorlette Cartwright, Verda Gardiner, and Alicia Wallace who inspired the participants of See My Island, our storytelling and climate action camp in The Bahamas.

Each of these women draws inspiration from the rich heritage and beautiful ecosystem of The Bahamas, and encourages participants to do the same. Tanicia Pratt's presentation inspired the girls to create their own poems and video skits using Bahamian dialect. Verda Gardiner, who designs fashion from native materials, inspired an upcycled fashion show using materials found around the camp.

Their work captures the vibrant culture and unique environment of The Bahamas. We're grateful to these artists for their invaluable contributions to See My Island, helping participants to explore their own creative power and become advocates for climate justice.

Although the Irish soccer team have been eliminated  from this year's FIFA Women’s World Cup many are labeling them as the honorary winner for their fight for equity in sports.

This year Ireland made its FIFA World Cup debut after winning a historic fight with the Footbal Association of Ireland (FIA). for equal pay between the men's and women's teams. The women's teams had been previously underfunded and were training on fields that were in terrible condition. Both the men's and women's teams collectively went on strike against the in FIA and the solidarity yielded in equal pay and a spot in the 2023 World Cup. demanding pay and resources.

During the tournament, Captain Katie McCabe (@katie_mccabe11) scored the first ever goal scored in a World Cup for Ireland and proved to the millions of viewers that their team deserved to be there. As they left the tournament Katie noted, “Back home in Ireland, I know that lots of little girls will be watching us ... And I'm just hoping with all my heart that some of them will be sitting there thinking, One day, I'm going to do that. If that happens, we have already won.

Photo: Mick O'Shea/Sportsfile/Getty Images

Investing in the youth of today can yield large dividends for our collective futures. By ensuring their education access, mental well-being, and access to opportunities, we pave the way for a more equitable world.

International Youth Day is a reminder that young voices deserve to be heard and valued. Let's create spaces so that their dreams can become reality. Learn more about how you can support youth and create more educational access by clicking on the link in our bio.

The lack of diversity in STEM has real-world consequences. Diverse perspectives boost creativity, allowing us to tackle complex challenges from different angles. Promoting gender equity in STEM can unleash the full potential of human ingenuity.

Gender biases and assumptions about who can succeed in STEM leads to girls being conditioned to not see themselves in STEM jobs. Surveys commissioned by Microsoft reveal that young girls often lose interest in STEM as they grow older due to these societal norms and stereotypes. We need to take serious, collective action to change how we talk to girls about STEM. We must empower them to break free from widespread stereotypes and embrace their passion for science and technology from an early age.

Six weeks ago, Senior Future Rising Fellow Lauren Ritchie (@laurenaritchie) was in Eleuthera, Bahamas leading See My Island, Girl Rising's new storytelling and climate action camp for young changemakers. Six days ago, she watched with the rest of us in horror as fires engulfed the island of Maui.

In an opinion piece Girl Rising published today, Lauren calls on the world to see the human faces behind the devastation. "Headlines about Maui’s devastation emphasizing the “tourist town” and “iconic getaway”, coupled with frustrated residents appalled by tourists snorkeling in the very waters where bodies were recovered just days prior, showcase how exploitative tourism dehumanizes and casts aside native populations,'' she says.

The Maui fires have claimed the lives of nearly 100 people as of today, displaced over 200 families and destroyed over 2,000 structures. We invite you to read Lauren's piece for a very personal view of the devastating impacts of climate change on island communities and ecosystems.

Click on the link in our bio to read more.

It's a game-changer and a sweeping win for 16 young environmentalists in Montana in a landmark case that holds government leaders accountable to do more to tackle climate change.

The plaintiffs, aged 5 through 22, asserted that Montana's energy policies violated their right to a clean and healthful environment, which is guaranteed in their state's constitution. The case marks the first time a U.S. court has declared that a government has a constitutional duty to protect people from climate change.

This win gives legal precedence for citizens to push for environmental protection as a part of their fundamental human rights. These 16 leaders are an inspiration for young people all over the world who also aspire to create a more safe, just and sustainable world. Congratulations to @OurChildren'sTrust on this game-changing legal action

Photo credit: Thom Bridge/AP

Introducing the Super Sheros and STEMinistas who led workshops and classes for See My Island, our free two-week storytelling and climate action camp for Bahamian girls. Expert divers, aquaculture engineers, and human rights defenders came together to inspire and empower these young participants, ages 11-16.

During the camp, the girls who are all committed environmental stewards, expanded their skills and knowledge alongside these inspiring mentors. Mia Avril shared her expertise on mangroves, while "Dolphin" Doon McKinney focused on environmental stewardship. Natalia Furtado and Silia Woodside delved into the world of coral reefs, and "Mermaid" Tonia Ferguson explored marine biology with the campers. Immersed in their natural environment, the girls deepened their understanding of their surrounding ecosystems, the changes due to climate change, and solutions to restoration and recovery.

The Rocket Women of India have done it again! India's Chandrayaan-3 successfully landed on the moon, making them the first nation to land on the South Pole. Over 54 women scientists and engineers played a key role in this mission and are being fondly celebrated and nicknamed by the Internet as the Rocket Women of India and the ISRO (Indian Space Research Organization) Saree Trailblazers. 

In 2013, ISRO first garnered praise for launching a successful Mars Orbiter with 27% of the key leadership roles in the mission held by women, which is considered progress for the sector. India became the first nation to have a successful maiden effort and the fourth nation to have an orbiter. This mission was celebrated as a historic glass ceiling breaking moment in a male dominated field and it has paved the way for more women participation in the Chandrayaan missions. 

“You know, we know Mars is for men, now we have proved that Mars is not only for men,” Scientist Subbiah Arunan joked referencing the popular saying, "Men are from Mars, women are from Venus."

Congratulations to the entire team of Chandrayaan - 3, especially the women creating more space for girls and women in STEM.

This month marked the two year anniversary of the Taliban takeover of Afghanistan. In these last two years Afghani girls and women have had grave setbacks to accessing their human rights. The Taliban has closed secondary schools for girls, banned women from attending university and working at Non-governmental Organizations -  including the United Nations - restricted their travel without a male chaperone, and prohibted them from being in public spaces such as parks and gyms.

Girl Rising stands with the international community in condemming these human rights violations, and as the Taliban continues its attempts to erase girls and women from public life, we hope to share the voices and the stories of Afghan girls who have fled the country. Two years ago, girls from the School of Leadership Afghanistan, the country’s only boarding school for girls, shared their hopes and dreams for a better future. We share them again here - and will continue to work to create a world where all girls can learn, rise, and thrive.

The climate crisis knows no boundaries, but its harshest consequences are disproportionately borne by those who contributed the least to its causes.

The richest 1% of the world’s population are responsible for more than twice as much carbon pollution as the 3.1 billion people who made up the poorest half of humanity during a critical 25-year period of unprecedented emissions growth, according to Oxfam International.

As advocates for a fairer world, we must raise our voices, demand justice, and hold the wealthiest nations accountable for their actions. Let's work together to rewrite this narrative, ensuring that everyone, regardless of economic status, can thrive in a safe and sustainable planet.

@laurenaritchie #GirlRising #FutureRising

At Girl Rising, we are challenging this through our Financial Education Initiative, which help adolescent girls focus on financial literacy, empowerment, goal setting, and gender equality. Girls in the program learn basic skills like budgeting, saving for college or entrepreneurial ventures, helping their community and more.

Equipping these girls with financial literacy will positively impact their communities, their nations and our whole world. Learn more about our initiative by clicking on the link in our bio.

Click on the link in our bio to watch the trailer to Astrid's movie and stay tuned for updates on her film.

At Girl Rising, we've seen firsthand the power stories hold – they're bridges to empathy and sparks that ignite change. That's why we have recently created a 10-week Storytelling Module, designed to guide adolescents as they harness their narratives for self-advocacy and community transformation.

Currently in its pilot phase in India and Kenya, the Storytelling Module is on track to reach over 1,000 adolescents.

"It's awe-inspiring to witness participants discovering the varied ways stories shape our world," shared Girl Rising President Nidhi Shukla. "Storytelling has always been at the core of our efforts, challenging norms and molding perspectives. Now, as these young voices embrace its potential, we eagerly anticipate the impact they'll make."

Hey Southern Californians, here's your chance to enjoy a music fest while making a difference! Above the Bridge, a music entertainment multi-media company is bringing together talented musicians for a benefit concert in Los Angeles for Girl Rising's work to advance girls' education.

The event will feature performers like Maddy Davis, BLUNÈ, Emi Grace and Ellie Williams. Click on the link in our bio to learn more and to get tickets.

Spread the word, invite your friends, and let's make this a night to remember! 💫

Historians date the movement to ensure girls' right to education as early as the 18th and 19th century and yet to this day education rights activists are fighting this significant barrier globally. Despite progress, global systems are still leaving out over 129 millions girls from accessing education. We cannot let down another generation of girls. We must act now to tackle this crisis!

As we recognize International Literacy Day this week, Girl Rising will amplify the importance of educating girls throughout this week. Follow our social media, share the content and advocate for girls' education to urge government leaders and world organizations to take more serious action to prioritize girls' education.

Amidst the escalating impacts of climate change, the impact on Future Rising Fellow Astrid Peraza’s coastal fishing community in Manzanillo, Costa Rica intensifies with each passing year. The community's primary livelihoods of fishing and tourism are bearing the brunt.

Astrid’s conviction is clear – global action and holding the biggest climate offenders accountable are critical. Equipping her community with climate literacy from a young age could help them weather the effects. "I consider education a key point in the protection of our planet," she says. "The lack of education is at the center of most social problems, and to fix this, we need to focus on accessibility. My community’s story would have been much different if someone had taught us about sustainable fishing practices, climate change, and how we needed to protect our limited resources."

In a recent article for Girl Rising, Astrid (@astridprzj) explores how dedicating a comprehensive subject to climate change could serve as a pivotal tool in arming the upcoming generation with the essential tools to confront this crisis. For a deeper exploration of her perspective, follow the link in our bio.

Once more for people in the back - when girls learn and rise, the world thrives.

Providing girls with an extra year of schooling can increase individual wages by up to 20%, which holds the potential to pull communities out of cycles of poverty. If all girls completed secondary education, child marriage rates could be reduced by two-thirds. When mothers receive at least five years of primary education, their children have a 40% higher chance of surviving past the age of five.

Girl Rising works with a global network of partners to increase education equity by teaching girls about voice, agency and self-advocacy. We also work with parents, teachers and community members to increase awareness about girls' education and advocate for inclusive policies.

Join us today in investing in girls' education by giving to Girl Rising. Click on the link in our bio to learn more.

Sources - World Bank, UNICEF, Global Partnership for Education

It's back to school time as classes are back in session in many parts of the world. Meet Ariste Metaxas, a talented and passionate educator in Florida and editor of our US Educator Newsletter. Ariste shows us a day in the life of an educator in the United States.

As students around the world resume their studies, here at Girl Rising we are laser-focused on advancing education equity. Today, 224,977 US children of primary school age are not enrolled in school according to UNESCO data. Discrimination, inequities and bullying are some of the reasons that are keeping students in the US out of school.

Learn more about education inequities in the US and how you can tackle them through Looking Inward, a Girl Rising education resource. Join Ariste and Girl Rising in amplifying the importance of tackling education inequity in the US.

Happy International Literacy Day! Let’s celebrate the power of reading, writing, and the limitless worlds they open up. Literacy isn’t just a skill – it’s a key that unlocks doors of opportunity and knowledge.

Today, let’s renew our commitment to ensure that every girl has the chance to build strong literacy foundations. When girls can read and write, they’re equipped with tools that shape their future and enable them to become active participants in their communities.

Join us in spreading the word about the importance of literacy for girls everywhere. Let’s work together to create a world where every girl’s story is heard and her potential is limitless.

In a world where schools and education systems should be a beacon of hope and progress, it’s disheartening to witness many children being subjected to attacks in these spaces.

Every child has the right to a safe and quality education. But, unfortunately, millions of students and educators face violence, displacement, and disrupted learning due to conflicts and attacks. Girl Rising’s partner 1 Million Teacher’s (1MT) Co-Founder Rizma Butt talks about the importance of creating safe educational spaces for children worldwide and how Girl Rising and 1MT (@onemillionteachers) are collaborating to make this possible.

On this International Day to Protect education from attack, join us in advocating for safer and more equitable educational spaces for children. 

Click on the link in our bio to read her insights.

Girl Rising is hiring!

Join our global team of talented, passionate changemakers who are advancing girls right to a quality education. Girl Rising has an exemplary culture of collaboration and creativity, and a strong sense of purpose and action.

Check out the job description via the link in our bio!

Morocco has recently experienced its deadliest earthquake in decades, claiming the lives of more than 2,500 people. Thousands of others are  injured and countless have been left homeless. Emergency services are working tirelessly to reach remote areas where people may still be trapped.

It's crucial to remember that natural disasters like this create especially vulnerable conditions for women and girls. The Girl Rising global community stands in solidarity with Morocco, mourning the losses and seeking ways to provide assistance to those most impacted, especially women and girls.

Here are four organizations where you can make a meaningful difference and support critical relief efforts:

Global Giving: Teaming up with Global Citizen, Global Giving collects funds and channels them to impactful local organizations, ensuring survivors receive shelter, food, water, menstrual supplies, and infant supplies. Visit GlobalGiving.org to contribute.

Moroccan Red Crescent Society (MRCS): MRCS, in collaboration with the International Federation of Red Cross, has dedicated rescue teams providing emergency care, social support, and transportation for the injured. Make your donation at Donation.ifrc.org.

CARE: CARE is actively accepting donations with a focus on prioritizing care for groups rendered especially vulnerable by the earthquake, including women, girls, youth, and marginalized communities. Support their efforts at my.care.org.

UNICEF: The United Nations' children's agency, UNICEF, is collecting donations to provide essential shelter, water, medical care, and social support, placing a special emphasis on youth and families. Join their cause at unicefuse.org.

Click on the link in our bio to find direct links to donate. Share your thoughts and spread the word by tagging someone who cares about making a difference. 

Photo credit: Philippe Lopez/AFP/Getty Images

The US Supreme Court's decision this summer effectively ended race-conscious admissions in higher education, removing a way for US colleges and universities to advance education equity and promote more diverse student bodies. In the wake of that decision, the first high school seniors to apply to college are grappling with conflicting guidance, college admission teams are looking at alternative ways to work toward fair admissions, and college guideance counselors are working through uncertainty.

In a powerful guest article for Girl Rising, Occidental College Student (@occidentalcollege), Obama Scholar and Education Rights Advocate Raja Bella Hicks (@rajabellaa) shares her story on how affirmative action has positively impacted her family and highlights vital actions that colleges and universities can take for education equity. 

"This ruling perpetuates the preexisting inequalities that minorities already face within the educational system," she says. "The idea that today, everyone has an equal and merit-based shot at higher education is a false narrative and fails to examine the barriers that race plays in both the historic and modern contexts of the US. Affirmative action set education equity as a national priority, but with the Supreme Court’s decision we must find ways to systematically reimagine what education for all looks like."

Click on the link in our bio to read more about her story and her recommendations on tangible steps individuals and institutions can take to navigate this critical juncture education policy.

Introducing the 2023 Future Rising Fellows!

These exceptional leaders were selected from a pool of over 600 applicants from around the world. Over the course of the next year, they will embark on a transformative journey, collaborating on projects that address the intersections of climate change and gender equity and creating stories of their work to share with a global audience.

Follow along on our social media this month to hear more of the personal stories of each one of the Fellows, insights from their communities and learn more about their projects. Thank you for your continued support in uplifting these young climate and gender equity leaders.

Girl Rising is hiring!

Join our global team of talented, passionate changemakers who are advancing girls right to a quality education. Girl Rising has an exemplary culture of collaboration and creativity, and a strong sense of purpose and action.

Check out the job description via the link in our bio!

Congratulations to this year's 1 Million Teachers' Blackbelt graduates!

The Blackbelt Program provides intensive and ongoing professional development support and opportunities to the most promising educators some of the most un-resourced regions in 20 African countries and Pakistan. Girl Rising works with 1 Million Teachers to help teachers develop teaching processes that dismantle gender biases in educational setting and build more gender sensitive curriculums.

Recently, Girl Rising's Kenya Program Manager Debbie Odenyi participated in 1 Million Teaches' graduation in Kenya, where 143 teachers were recognized advancing in the Blackbelt program. In 2023 2,600 teachers have already graduated from the program and a total 10,946 are signed up for 1 Million Teacher's training sessions. To learn more about our collaboration with 1 Million Teachers (@onemillionteachers) click on the link in our bio.

Meet Sushmita Krishnan, Future Rising Fellow, India!

Sushmita is part of our 2023 cohort of Fellows and is an ecologist pursuing her doctoral degree in environmental education at the Center for Sustainable Future in Coimbatore, India. She has received fellowships from the Indian Academy of Sciences and worked in collaboration with UNESCO’s Digital Games for Peace program as an individual specialist. She is an advocate for sustainability.

Sushmita’s Future Rising Project is an interactive story about an invasive tree in Indian Forests, Lantana camara, and the entrepreneurial ingenuity of tribal women to repurpose this tree into furniture to create sustainable businesses. She tells the story of these women who lack primary education and live isolated within Indian forests leading sustainable business opportunities.

Throughout this month you will see and hear from the members of 2023 Future Rising Fellows as they talk about their dreams and aspirations, and their Future Rising projects. Stay tuned!

Meet Andrea Villarreal Rodríguez, Future Rising Fellow, Mexico!

Andrea Villarreal Rodríguez is a visual storyteller and environmental activist. Her work highlights the leadership of girls and women in addressing the climate crisis. She is a National Geographic Young Explorer and Communications Fellow at Girl Up Mexico— a United Nations Foundation initiative for gender equality. In 2022, she founded the Girl Up Mexico Storytelling Lab, empowering youth to craft impactful narratives through documentary film.

Her Future Rising Project is a short film about a group of women and their campaign as urban citizen scientists to save the urban ecology of the Santa Catarina River. This body of water, endangered by rapid urban growth and pollution, flows through Monterrey, Mexico. This group works as a collective, called “Journey to the Microcosmos,” to document the unique biodiversity of the river and rebuild the city’s relationship to the natural resource.

Stay tuned to meet more of the 2023 Future Rising Fellows!

No more excuses, no more pay disparities, and no more gender discrimination in the workplace! It is time for us to collectively demand for equaly pay for equal work.

Share this post to shine a light on how in 2023 gender wage dispairty is still a prevalent issue and is withhodling women reaching their full potential.

Future Rising Fellow Tia Kennedy (@kinew_kwe ), First Nations Canada delivered the Call to Action at a United Nations General Assembly side event hosted by Global Partnership for Education and Population Council (@gpforeducation). Her words at The Intersections of Gender, Education, and Climate Action shed light on the need for immediate action to protect the rights of Indigenous people, particularly Indigenous girls who experience some of the worst impacts of climate change. Tia joins Future Rising Fellows from all three cohorts over the next two weeks in New York City at UNGA and Climate Week, advocating for urgent solutions for girls' rights, climate action, and equity.

Read her full remarks by clicking on the link in our bio.

text_entities.entity: global partnership for education and population council

social_posts.post_text:
When two powerhouses come together! Prolific Climate Activist and Future Rising Fellow, Chile, Julieta Martinez (@julietamartinezo) and Former New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern (@jacindaardern) connected for a panel at the Women Rise for All luncheon as part of the United Nations General Assembly.

Julieta is the founder of Tremendas, a global action platform that brings together more than 2,000 young activists from 18 countries around the world. The organization is designed to connect girls and young women who support social justice and bring together their talents. Over the last five years, their platform has continued to grow and enabled positive spaces for adolescents to cultivate their voices for advocacy.

In their "feminist action for climate justice," Tremendas members focus on girls' education as a climate solution as a main driver of change. Their Climate Academy offers 600 Latin American girls with quality environmental education from a feminist lens, which seeks to train young girls as climate activist leaders and provide knowledge to identify problems and act to solve them. Julieta continues to be an inspiration for all young people hoping to change the world.

Follow @tremendascl to learn more and get involved.

Here's a quick recap of Girl Rising at UNGA78! This year's United General Assembly has been a momentous gathering, bringing together 150 heads of state, human rights advocates, nonprofit leaders, and climate advocates from Girl Rising's own Future Rising Fellowship program!

The Fellows and Girl Rising staff have been on the front lines of marches, championing the urgent need for climate action on UN world stages and exploring sustainable change with world leaders and influencers.

The common theme was how tackling climate change can positively impact all human rights areas. "In many ways, we see the climate crisis as a communications challenge," said Girl Rising CEO Christina Lowery. "We know what is causing the climate crisis. We know what the problems are. We know what needs to happen to make it better. But we do NOT have political will to make the necessary changes to reduce emissions, nor is there enough political will  to address the crushing inequities in terms of loss and damage. But we are really well positioned to coordinate our efforts to make our work more than the sum of its parts through more action and more collaboration in service of girls everywhere who are doing the work and we must act now!"

Click on the link in our bio to read Christina's full remarks at Reimagining the Future: Centering Education, Gender, and Climate for a Sustainable World, an UNGA side event hosted by @gpforeducation and Population Council

Thank you, Future Rising Fellow Julieta Martinez, for bringing vital attention to prioritizing girls' education on important world stages. Here she is meeting with legendary tennis player and education rights advocate Roger Federer and education rights activists at UNGA78 side event Investing in Education Systems for Sustainable Development and Children's Wellbeing.

The event, co-hosted by GPE, the Roger Federer Foundation, the Government of Kenya, UNICEF and co-sponsored by the Government of Switzerland, explored solutions to make preschool education a reality for all. Through her organization @tremendascl Julieta is channelling the power of girls and young people to tackle climate change related issues that often keep girls out of school. To learn more about her work follow @tremendascl and @julietamartinezo

Meet Selma Bichbich, Future Rising Fellow, Algeria!

Selma Bichbich is an Algerian climate youth activist. She co-founded the Middle East and North Africa (MENA) Youth Network to engage young people across the region on climate and human rights issues. She represents North Africa at the Global Youth Leadership Council in the EarthUprising NGO, and is one of the Center of United Nations Constitutional Research delegates. She will serve as the delegate of Algeria at the Conference of Parties (COP) 27. Her work advocates for civic engagement and global unity to promote a sustainable future of stability. She works with youth across the MENA region to combat negative climate impacts for vulnerable communities. She is  pursuing a Bachelor’s degree in Political Science in Lebanon.

Selma’s Future Rising Project is a social media campaign to share the experiences of young people affected by climate change through blog entries, articles, and videos. This campaign will highlight resilience and emphasize the local solutions in Algeria, the Mediterranean, and the MENA regions.

Follow us to meet more of the 2023 Future Rising Fellows, who will be advancing gender and climate equity!

Meet Shakhzoda Mirakova, Future Rising Fellow, Uzbekistan!

Shakhzoda Mirakova is an aspiring journalist and documentary filmmaker from Uzbekistan. As an Uzbekistan Youth Leadership Program fellow, Shakhzoda received resources and funding to start EcoChange– an initiative where 100 volunteers found homes for 250 trees in Bukhara to combat deforestation. In February 2023, she was selected to represent Uzbekistan and her perspective on gender equality at the Harvard Conference for Asian and International Relations in Massachusetts. Her work highlights Central Asian voices and their stories of climate resilience.  She is pursuing a degree in Journalism at the American University of Central Asia in Kyrgyzstan.

Shakhzoda’s Future Rising Project is an article and photo essay about a young woman fighting against pollution and deforestation in her hometown. The project follows a woman whose bravery made her a national activist, who continues this work today as the initiator of the ecological movement in Uzbekistan.

Meet more 2023 Future Rising Fellows on our page!

Meet Khongorzul Batbayar, Future Rising Fellow, Mongolia!

Khongorzul is an educator from Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia; she works to close the divide between youth in rural and urban areas while creating deeper connections to the environment and conservation. She currently works as a program coordinator at the Mongol Ecology Center where their youth programs incorporate Mongolian nomadic culture and heritage into conservation education. While Khongorzul mainly focuses on youth education, she has begun to work with the rangers of protected areas of Mongolia and isolated communities in the fight against the climate threats of desertification and overgrazing.

Khongorzul’s Future Rising Project is a short film about a woman who works as a National Park Ranger to protect the environment and her journey as a young woman in a field dominated by older men. Her story highlights the critical job of Mongolian Rangers and their role in educating youth and engaging local communities to fight climate change together.

Stay tuned to meet more of the 2023 Future Rising Fellows!

Meet Collins Busuru, Future Rising, Kenya!

Collins Busuru is a wildlife biologist based in Amboseli, Kenya; he works to protect wildlife through conservation education and ecosystem restoration. In his role at the Center for Human Development— Conservation Kenya, Collins engages with the local community to provide education and resources in the face of deforestation, overgrazing, and drought, to foster climate resilience. Collins and his team in Amboseli run a mentorship program for local Maasai girls, empowering young women to pursue their education.

Collins’ Future Rising Project will focus on the stories of these young Maasai girls and their relationship to nature. Located just outside Amboseli National Park at the base of Mt. Kilimanjaro, these young women learn skills to conserve their land in the face of worsening drought and threats from dangerous wildlife.

Visit our page to meet more 2023 Future Rising Fellows!

Meet Maria Yaschenko, Future Rising, Argentina!

Maria Yaschenko is a Russian-Ukrainian LGBT refugee and environmental advocate living in Argentina. She is a hydro-meteorologist and environmental education activist. She works to provide education access to vulnerable populations by teaching online courses for children lacking education opportunities, and hopes to launch a program to provide additional support. In her hydro-meteorology work, she studied climate change impacts by modeling Amazon River discharge.

Maria’s Future Rising Project is a film documenting the prominent women across Argentina making strides in climate and environmental justice work. Her project will highlight the issues facing the region and the women working to tackle climate change.

Visit our page to meet more of the 2023 Future Rising Fellows!

Meet Anjali Boyd (@anjaliboyd), Future Rising Fellow, United States!

Anjali D. Boyd is a marine ecologist, educator, entrepreneur, and elected official from North Carolina. Her research focuses on developing cost-effective restoration and management practices to restore and conserve vulnerable marine ecosystems. Anjali is a National Science Foundation Graduate Research Fellow, Ford Fellow, and National Geographic Explorer. As the Director of iNviTechnology, she works to combat the underrepresentation of women and ethnic minorities in science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM) fields through educational, entrepreneurial programs for children. Anjali also serves as an elected official in her hometown of Durham, N.C., as a Durham County Soil and Water Conservation District Supervisor.  She is a Ph.D. Candidate and Dean’s Graduate Fellow in the Nicholas School of the Environment at Duke University.

Anjali’s Future Rising Project is a short film that tells the story of a group of Black women marine scientists’ journey through the field of marine science. The film focuses on the importance of friendship to help these women persevere through adversity and hopes to inspire young Black women to see themselves as the future of marine biology.

Stay tuned to meet more 2023 Future Rising Fellows!

Meet Dayana Blanco Quiroga, Future Rising Fellow, Bolivia!

Dayana Blanco Quiroga is an Aymara Indigenous woman from Oruro, Bolivia, and the first Indigenous professional woman in her family. She co-founded the Uru Uru Team— an initiative focused on saving Uru Uru Lake from harmful pollution through Indigenous traditional knowledge. The lake is a vital source of life for the surrounding Indigenous communities under threat from mining, wastewater, and activity, causing immense pollution. The Uru Uru Team seeks to use Indigenous traditional knowledge to address these local environmental challenges and spread awareness of these harmful practices and industries.

Dayana’s Future Rising Project will be a multicultural and bilingual graphic novel, with both Aymara native dialect and English, to tell the story of Uru Uru Lake from Aymara ancestors to the present day. The book explains the environmental threats to the lake and highlights the work of the Uru Uru Team to restore a collective understanding of the lake’s importance for the community.

Click on the link in our bio to learn more about our Future Rising program and our Fellows.

Meet 13-year-old Nancy Sarfo, a young girl with dreams as vast as the open skies. As a part of Girl Rising’s Financial Education Initiative (FEI) in Ghana, she discovered the power of her voice and agency, and also became a fierce advocate for other girls like her younger sister.

When her sister was advised to give up her dream of becoming a flight attendant for ‘more realistic’ aspirations like becoming a seamstress, Nancy championed her sister’s dreams as valid and worth pursuing. Nancy shared her FEI knowledge– educating her sister about gender biases, her rights, self-advocacy, and the ability to save for her dream career in the airline industry - whether as a pilot, engineer, or flight attendant. She’s learned that education and financial literacy provide options and control of her future. Together they successfully changed the mindsets of their family and gained support for their passions.

Through the FEI, Nancy has developed the financial literacy skills to manage her own funds for her career goal of becoming a judge. Nancy believes that as a judge, she can ensure justice in her community and advocate for many. Through her perseverance, self-confidence, and acquired skills, Nancy has the potential to make a transformative impact on her entire community.

Starting today and until October 11th, International Day of the Girl, we’ll share one story a day that highlights the strength of girls and their allies. Follow along and share your own using the hashtag #11DaysOfStories to join the Girl Rising global community in harnessing the power of storytelling for change.

When Tracy noticed her relatives facing challenges managing menstruation amidst rising costs in Kenya, she saw potential solutions in her fashion design education.

Tracy ingeniously crafted reusable menstrual supplies and guided her community in creating their own cost-effective menstrual management tools. She emerged as a strong advocate for breaking down period stigma, mobilizing her community to foster open conversations about reproductive health.

Tracy embodies our belief at Girl Rising: a single girl can ignite positive change in her community. As we continue sharing stories of girls and their allies until October 11, International Day of the Girl, join us in amplifying your own stories using the hashtag #11DaysOfStories.

While progress has been made in creating pathways for women in STEM, the gender gap persists in the conservation sector. Meet Kenyan Wildlife Conservationist Victoria Wanjohi, dedicated to expanding opportunities for girls and women in conservation.

Victoria is the founder and editor of Nyika Silika, an award-winning environmental communication platform, and co-founder of Biophilic Conversations, inspiring African youth to join the conservation community. She currently serves as Director and Impact Communications at TonyWild Foundation. Explore Victoria’s wildlife work in Kenya on her blog at nyikasilika.org.

Victoria’s story is part of Girl Rising’s 11 Days of Stories, shared since October 1 and continuing through International Day of the Girl on October 11. Join the campaign by sharing your own #girlleaders stories using the hashtag #11DaysOfStories.

For countless girls and women, the simple act of accessing quality education or going to work becomes a daunting challenge as they navigate pervasive sexual harassment and sexual assault.

Jeeya Thukral, a young poet participating in Girl Rising’s partner program, Slam Out Loud, offers a powerful glimpse into the life of an Indian woman today. She narrates the experiences of witnessing a world that often blames victims of sexual assault, vilifies girls and women who advocate for their rights, and erects barriers that hinder them from competing on an equal footing with their male counterparts.

Girl Rising and Slam Out Loud have joined forces, leveraging the transformative power of creative arts—through theater, storytelling, or spoken word poetry—with youth in India’s most marginalized communities. Through these artistic mediums, young people build essential skills such as communication, critical thinking, and empathy.

Jeeya’s story is just one in a series of narratives we’ve been sharing since the beginning of October, all harnessing the power of storytelling to reshape perceptions of girls and women. Stay close to our social media channels to discover more stories - and share your own using the hashtag #11DaysOfStories, as we advocate for a more equitable world through storytelling.

Afghan women living across the globe are breaking the silence and standing in solidarity with the millions of girls and women in Afghanistan who have lost their rights under the oppressive rule of the Taliban.

In her latest video, Afghan filmmaker, poet, human rights activist, and dedicated member of the Girl Rising community, Aryan Shory (@aryanshory), brings together a resilient community of Afghan girls and women worldwide. They are using their stories and experiences to advocate passionately for the rights of Afghan girls and women who are now living in the darkness of oppression.

Together, they shine a light on girls and women in Afghanistan, where access to education, bodily autonomy, and fundamental rights has been unjustly denied.

Let’s unite our collective platforms and voices to champion the rights and futures of Afghan girls and women. Share your own stories and advocate for girls’ rights using the hashtag
#11daysofstories

Elsie Ashiono, a Kenyan environmental educator, visited Amboseli National Park with a mix of emotions. She marveled at the park’s beauty but was also disheartened by the damage caused by climate change, leading to droughts and famine.

These climate events are hurting local communities, especially girls who face high dropout rates from school and forced marriages. Elsie, who values the traditional wisdom of land stewardship and wildlife protection passed down through generations, believes that girls can play a unique role in environmental protection. Unfortunately, climate-related barriers hinder their education and involvement.

Elsie, as an environmental educator, urges her community to recognize girls’ education as a solution to climate challenges. She notes, “Currently, there aren’t enough girls and women in environmental work due to educational barriers that limit exposure to scientific disciplines. Gender stereotypes also play a role, with many believing that girls lack the power to make a difference. We must create more opportunities for girls and women in environmental protection.”

Just over a year ago, the tragic death of Mahsa Amini while in Iran’s police custody ignited the world’s outrage. And today, the rage burns hot still as our concern turns toward 16-year-old Armita Geravand, currently in a coma after surveillance footage caught her being removed, unconscious from a train, with uncovered hair.

Girl Rising condemns these violent acts that infringe on human rights and keep girls and women from full bodily autonomy. Khuzama Khan, Girl Rising’s Director of Program Quality and Learning, shares her own story of choosing to wear the hijab as a 15-year-old, then changing her mind later. Informed by her own personal experiences, she advocates for a world where every girl has the freedom to choose all decisions surrounding her body and enjoys the full spectrum of human rights. Read about Khuzama’s personal journey and perspective by clicking the link in our bio.

Homelessness is a profound challenge, one that extends far beyond the absence of a roof over one’s head. It’s a harsh barrier that not only strips away shelter but also deprives girls of their basic rights to safety, privacy and education. In this story, meet Nazma, a remarkable teenager who, against all odds, refused to let the circumstances of homelessness dictate her destiny.

To watch the full story of Nazma discovering the way off the streets of Kolkatta and out of the cycle of poverty, click on the link in our bio. And join Girl Rising’s global community in telling your own stories of girl power and change by using the hashtag #11DaysOfStories

Phoebe Matunda fell in love with nature and wildlife in her childhood as she talked to her grandmother about elephants for hours. She grew up to be an environmentalist conservationist who equips young people who share her passion with skills and knowledge to lead conservation efforts in their communities.

Phoebe believes that solving problems in conservation and climate change, starts with empowering young people – especially girls. Around the world girls are trained to be stewards of land, caretakers of animals and supporters of households. As a result they bring an abundance of lived experiences to solving environmental challenges.

Phoebe is championing the next generation of changemakers as Programs Director of Stand Up Shout Out, a youth environmental action, movement, and Co-Found of Own Your Crown, a girls’ leadership and empowerment organization. Follow her @_2nda_ to learn more about her conservation efforts in Kenya.

The Maasai people, known for their nomadic way of life and deep connection to wildlife and the land, face an unprecedented challenge – the relentless impact of climate change. Meet Collins Busuru (@busurucollins) a Kenyan Wildlife Biologist, Conservation Educator, and Future Rising Fellow. Since 2019, he’s been working closely with the Maasai community, witnessing their resilience in the face of mounting climate-related challenges.

On Indigenous People’s Day, we celebrate the invaluable wisdom of the Maasai people and why it’s crucial to include their insights in creating effective climate action plans. Share this post to amplify the importance of involving Indigenous communities in local, regional, and global decision-making.

Collins’ narrative about the Maasai community is part of our ongoing series, “11 Days of Stories,” which we’ve been sharing throughout October, leading up to International Day of the Girl. Join this campaign by sharing your own stories of girl power and change, using the hashtag #11DaysOfStories.

There’s no limit to what girls can achieve when they have the support and resources they need. Azmera’s story is proof of this as she, along with her brother, challenges the norms of forced marriage in Ethiopia, finding their own voice and agency.

Across the world, millions of girls still face barriers that hold them back from living life on their own terms and realizing their full potential. These barriers include gender biases, conflicts, public health crises, and more. A better world begins with unlocking the incredible potential of girls.

This International Day of the Girl, let’s come together to share stories of girls and their allies. Use the hashtag #11DaysOfStories to join the conversation. In the comments, tag a girl or a champion of girls’ rights and share why they inspire you.

Inspired by the original “Girl Rising” film, students and staff at Quincy High School in Massachusetts founded the Quincy High Girl Rising club, a dynamic youth-led initiative dedicated to championing the rights of girls and women. Over the years, club members have organized fundraisers in support of various girls’ and women’s rights organizations, including Girl Rising.

Around the globe, Girl Rising student ambassadors are igniting change on pressing issues like period poverty, food scarcity, climate change, and more.

This International Day of the Girl, we celebrate these young leaders and advocates for girls’ rights worldwide who are tirelessly working to turn gender equality into a reality for all. Join us in amplifying the stories of girls and their allies in your community using the hashtag #11DaysOfStories. In the comments, tag a girl or a dedicated champion of girls’ rights and share why they inspire you. Together, let’s make our voices heard!

Girl Rising stands with the United Nations, WHO and other global human rights organizations in condemning the senseless acts of violence in Israel and the Occupied Palestinian Territory (OPT).

We call for an immediate de-escalation, and for upholding and respecting international humanitarian law. We particularly recognize that in conflict areas girls and women are disproportionately and gravely impacted, and urge for the protection of all civilians.

In this time of heightened violence, we hold space for those who are hurting and grieving at this massive loss. 

To support women and girls affected by the violence of conflict, please follow: @unwomen
@globalfundwomen @womenforwomen

To read more of the UN’s reporting surrounding the situation in Israel and OPT click on the link in our bio.

Girl Rising and our partner, Drawing Dreams Initiative (@drawingdreams_initiative), hosted "Storytelling Over Chai" to celebrate International Day of the Girl. With over 100 participants, young people came together to share the inspiring stories they've created through the new Girl Rising Storytelling module. Over cups of warm and spicy chai tea, they poured their hearts out, sharing their unique experiences, and dreams for the future.

We hosted Storytelling Over Chai in Naibor, a vibrant Maasai community in Nanyuki, Laikipia County. Storytelling holds deep cultural significance in Maasai traditions, and through our pilot program, we're harnessing the power of storytelling to empower young individuals, including many from the Maasai community, helping them develop essential skills and realize their potential as change-makers. The day was filled with joy, the rhythm of music, and the bonds of new connections. Join us in celebrating the power of storytelling and the incredible potential of these young changemakers!

You heard that right, climate change is a gender issue!

Across the world women bear a disproportionate responsibility for securing food, water, and fuel and during periods of drought, erratic rainfall and natural disasters there is an added pressure on girls to leave school to help their mothers manage the increased burden. This makes climate justice and gender equity deeply linked issues.

To achieve climate justice, we must ensure gender equality:

✅ Inclusion: Women's voices must be heard and valued in climate discussions and decision-making processes.

✅ Education: Access to education for girls and women is critical for building climate resilience and sustainable practices.

✅ Economic Empowerment: Economic opportunities for women can lead to sustainable livelihoods and climate-friendly businesses.

✅ Leadership: Encouraging women's leadership in environmental sectors and policymaking is key to driving meaningful change.

Hey Swifties and fellow Earth advocates! It's time we harness our collective power to address one of the most pressing issues of our time: the CLIMATE CRISIS.

Climate change affects everyone, everywhere and this is the only planet we've got. We're all in this together, and together we can make a difference. Hold corporations, world leaders and organizations accountable for more ethical and serious climate action plans.

Girls who live in rural areas still have the highest barriers to education among adolescent groups across the world. Rural girls often confront long journeys to school, limited resources, and cultural biases that hinder their education. 
It's time to bridge the gaps in education gaps among rural girls and women.

This International Day of Rural Women, commit with us to advocate for more inclusive education policies that prioritize rural girls' education.

On #WorldFoodDay, let's seize an incredible opportunity - leveling the playing field for women in agriculture. Did you know that if women had equal access to financial and technological resources, we could potentially increase global food production and reduce hunger by a staggering 150 million people?

Women reinvest up to 90% of their earnings back into their families, covering essentials like nutrition, healthcare, education, and more. This ripple effect breaks the cycle of poverty and uplifts generations.

This World Food Day, let us recognize the valuable contributions of girls and women in food security and ensure they have more equitable access to continue their work to nourish the world.

Source: United Nations Environment Programme

Poverty often traps generations within its vicious cycle but here's a powerful truth - educated girls can shatter its cycle. Providing girls with an extra year of schooling can increase individual wages by up to 20%, sparking ripple effects that changes lives, communities and nations.

Together, let's invest in education and uplift girls to be the change-makers of tomorrow! Click on the link in our bio to learn more about how you can get involved with Girl Rising to increase girls' access to a quality education.

Source: UNESCO

Girl Rising CEO Christina Lowery shares insights from her 18-month-long Aspen Women and Girls SOAR Fellowship journey. She connected with 17 remarkable women leaders, champions of economic justice, women’s health, education equity, and gender equality, who are driving change with bold and innovative solutions. 🌍💙

During the SOAR fellowship, each fellow proposed a Big Idea. Christina’s was Future Rising—our leadership-development, storytelling and advocacy initiative focused on girls’ education as a climate solution. Her article shares more about the SOAR Fellows, her personal experiences and the Big Idea plans for Future Rising. ✨

Ready to be part of this transformative journey? Click the link in our bio to learn more!

Every day is a day to champion girls' rights!

While International Day of the Girl was a powerful reminder, our commitment to girls' education and opportunity is constant. And here's how you can support gender equity every day:

🗣️ Speak up against everyday misogyny and microaggressions.
🌟 Create more leadership spaces for girls and women.
🗳️ Vote for inclusive policies and candidates.
💙 Donate to girls' rights nonprofits like Girl Rising. Click the link in our bio to learn more.

Throughout this month and beyond, Girl Rising will continue using the power of storytelling to challenge bias and shatter harmful gender norms. Follow along to see more inspiring stories from our Girl Rising community of girls leading change in their communities.
And let's all commit to advocating for girls' rights 365 days a year to build a world 
where all children can learn, rise and thrive!

Meet the Inspiring Women Nobel Laureates of 2023 - Narges Mohammadi is risking her life to fight for the rights of her fellow citizens and women around the world. Claudia Goldin dug into more than a century of data to illuminate the truth about gender equity. Anne L’Huillier developed breakthroughs so that we 
can see electrons. Katalin Karikó saved millions and millions of lives.

Click on the link on our bio to learn their stories of resilience, dedication, and the pursuit of gender equity.

Meet Charitie Ropati, Future Rising Fellow, Yup’ik & Sāmoan, Alaska Native and Pacific Islander.

Charitie Ropati is an activist and ecologist of Yup’ik and Samoan heritage who researches the connections between plant ecology, permafrost, and cultural resilience in coastal Native communities. She is an Arctic Youth Ambassador, an Arctic Resilient Youth Communities Fellow, and an Aspen Ideas Fellow. She co-founded a nonprofit “lilnativegirlinSTEM” which promotes equity in STEM for Indigenous women and girls and works to create access to education and climate justice for Indigenous people. She is pursuing a Bachelor’s degree in civil engineering and anthropology at Columbia University.

Charitie’s Future Rising Project is a short film highlighting Indigenous women with successful careers. She hopes the film will inspire and aid young girls in navigating academia and the workforce. In addition to the short film, Charitie hopes to create workshops for young Indigenous girls to share their experiences and stories.

Meet more 2023 Future Rising Fellows on our page!

When Ojibwe native and high schooler Danielle Boyer joined the robotics team in high school, she realized how out of reach robotics are for low-income families. Since then, she’s made it her mission to create free robot kits to connect other Indigenous youth to the tech skills that will shape their future.

We are thrilled to support the MIT Solve (@SolveMIT) three part film series, “The Big Idea: Indigenous Robotics” which tells Danielle’s and her robot kits that connect
Indigenous youth to tech skills that will shape their future.

Produced by @redglasspics and made possible by the generous support of @HP. This film follows the lives of @solvemit innovators who are brilliant, bold, and united by
the desire to use technology, science and engineering to create radical, systemic change. Click on the link in our bio to watch the film series.

Introducing Apurva Vurity, the newest addition to Girl Rising's team as our India Program Manager!

Apurva has 6+ years of experience in impact-driven project management and strategic communications in the social sector in India. Her diverse roles across community-based organizations, international NGOs, political and social impact consulting helped her understand the sector and its role deeply. Through her work in organizations such as Dasra, Girl Effect, MTV Staying Alive Foundation, Prerana, and Indian Political Action Committee, Apurva used the power of storytelling, research and communications to contribute towards long term impact amongst the most vulnerable communities in Asia. Apurva’s education in Literature and Women’s Studies played a key role in inspiring her to work in the social sector and to bring a gender-sensitive perspective to the table. She firmly believes in the power of empathetic listening and always aspires to channelize that belief system into her work.

Earlier this month on International Day of the Girl, Girl Rising and and our partner Drawing Dreams Initiative (@drawingdreams_initiative ) brought together girls and their allies to share stories, sing, and dance, all in honor of the amazing strength and potential of girls around the world.

Girl across Kenya and rest of the world have a unique story to tell, a song to sing, and a dance to inspire change. Let’s amplify their voices every day until every girl has access to live a life of her own design. Click on the link in our bio to learn how you can get involved today.

Video by @kelvimaina

social_posts.post_text:
Meet Ugandan Girl Rising Student Ambassador Nantume Masturah, who turned her battle with menstrual product inaccessibility into a mission for change. Through her successful fundraising strategies she has been able to support 370 girls in her community, building their skills and providing them with the resources to make their own reusable menstrual supplies. Her experience led her to found the nonprofit Youngsters’ Appeal (@youngstersappeal) to make easy accessibility to period products a reality for more Ugandans.

“Periods must not be a reason to end girls’ dreams,” she says. “Every girl should be in school! Together, we can ensure that no girl’s dreams are shattered due to a lack of sanitary pads.”

Nantume is one of hundreds of Girl Rising Student Ambassadors that are creating change in their own communities and coming together to be inspired by each other and channel the power of the Girl Rising global community to change the way world values girls and their education. Learn more about our Student Ambassador program in the link in our bio.

A few weeks ago Future Rising Fellow, Argentina, Maria Yaschenko joined thousands of people across South America and the world in the #NiUnPasoAtrás protest. Maria participated in marches in Buenos Aires, Argentina,  advocating against governmental policies to ban abortion, cancel sex education, and disband human rights organizations.

Maria and #genderrights advocates in this movement are also defending their right to health, education, and freedom, and condeming politicians’ denial of global warming and their criticism of environmental programs. To learn more about Maria’s advocacy click on the link in our bio.

At Girl Rising, we're passionate about driving change on a global scale. That's why our team regularly participates in world forums across the planet. Recently, Director of Global Programs Richa Hingorani and Development 
Director Cris Valderrama represented Girl Rising at the Opportunity Collobartion (OC) in the Domincan Republic, sharing insights and innovative approaches with nonprofit leaders and changemakers.

During the four-day session participants explored vital topics including trust-based philanthropy. "All relationships, whether professional or personal are reliant on trust to succeed, and any significant trust deficit can 
undermine and harm that relationship," Richa shares. Such conversations help Girl Rising continue to build culture of nonprofit transparency and trust. 

To hear more from Richa on this topic and her experiences at the OC visit the link in our bio.

Girl Rising's Development Director Cris Valderrama joined Global Programs Director Richa Hingorani (@richahingorani) at the #OpportunityCollaboration (OC) in the Domincan Republic earlier this month - building partnerships and driving global collaboration to tackle gender inequity head-on - thanks to the generosity and support of Julie Goldstein and the Swaha Foundation (@swahafoundation).

Cris collaborated with nonprofit leaders from Kenya, Ghana, Bolivia, India, Peru, and Nicaragua exploring solutions for some of the most pressing issues of our time. "Investing in leadership development opportunities and facilitating spaces for nonprofit leaders to collaborate and share solutions with a global community is key to tackling world challenges in cooperation, as a team, as a whole.," says Cris.

Read more about Cris' remarks from the OC by clicking on the link in our bio.

Meet Colombian high school student, girls' rights advocate and Girl Rising Student Ambassador Laura Cubillos Guzman! As a Student Ambassador Laura hopes to ignite change on gender rights - especially the rights of girls and women in conflict areas. 

Colombia has experienced five decades long armed conflict 
due to political unrest and drug trafficking and while girls and
women are most impacted, Laura believes they also hold the power to provide solutions through STEM. Laura is combating the impacts of the conflict through her work with the Colombian nonprofit, @ASOFI, who connect young women in STEM for peace building and rural development in Colombia. 

Laura believes that when girls and women support each other 
they are unstoppable. "I was inspired to become a Girl Rising 
Student ambassador because I learned that changes only happen through collective impact," she says. "We all have to work towards gender equality and there is no better way of starting than working with your community with the support of girls in the Student Ambassador program all over the planet."

Click on the link in our bio to learn more about our Student Ambassador program.

We are delighted to announce Zainab Bie as the winner of the 2023 Natasha Steven Legacy Fund Award.

Zainab is a 20-year old Indian economics college student and climate justice advocate who is on a mission to combat the climate crisis through public policy, climate action, and sustainable development partnerships. She used her award to host an awareness and climate advocacy event in her hometown, Delhi, for more than 75 college-aged participants. Zainab spoke from her own experience on the importance of youth participation in climate action. The event also provided attendees with invaluable networking opportunities, enabling them to connect and collaborate with like-minded climate and gender advocates.

“Recognizing that women are disproportionately affected by climate change and environmental degradation, I wanted to create an event that highlights the vital role girls and women play in the fight against climate change and environmental degradation,” she says. “We need to focus on addressing the root causes of inequality and discrimination, so we can create a world where every person can live with dignity and respect."

Click on the link our bio for an exclusive look at our conversation with Zainab to learn more about her eco-feminism advocacy work.

Breaking the barriers in conservation! Collins Busuru, a Future Rising Fellow from Kenya, recently spearheaded a Wildlife Research camp in Kenya in partnership with CHD Conservation Kenya. His mission? To inspire girls to shatter gender stereotypes and explore careers in conservation.

A group of remarkable girls, aged 13 to 18, attended the camp. They didn't just learn about wildlife; they gained valuable skills like time management, advocacy, and an exclusive peek into the world of conservation from industry leaders.

Collins passionately believes that we need more male allies to step up and create spaces for girls and women to thrive in conservation. He underlines, 'Girls have been overlooked for far too long, limiting their potential as leaders and their capacity to drive meaningful climate action and contribute to environmental and wildlife conservation.'

In a male-dominated conservation sector, Collins recognizes that girls and women bring a wealth of Indigenous knowledge, passed down through generations, about land stewardship and animal care. This knowledge could be the key to solving longstanding conservation challenges that still need answers.

To learn more about Collins' work follow him @busurcollins

Meet Riya, a 10th-grade student in our Storytelling Program in India, where the influence of Malala Yousafzai resonates globally. After immersing herself in stories of role models from around the world, Riya turned to her peers and passionately declared, 'Just as Malala raised her voice for girls' education, we too possess the potential to spark change within our village and champion girls' education.'

Riya embodies the essence of Girl Rising's Storytelling Program, which helps adolescents harness the #powerofstorytelling for social change. Our curriculum includes inspirational narratives, like Malala's, helping young people develop their voice and power as #changemakers.

Fueled by the courage and determination of leaders like Malala, these young people are helping to #RewritetheFuture.

@Malala @slamoutloud

GEMS Rock!!! 💎 The newest cohort of GEMS at PS/MS 124 in Queens, New York City kicked off the school year by looking inward to think about their strengths, powers and attributes - and then put their creativity to work to create personalized and bedazzled word stones.

"Resilience," "Courage," "Kindness," "Creativity," "Beauty," and a host of other superpowers now adorn the rocks of these gem-tastic GEMS. These middle schoolers shine brightly, and at Girl Rising, we're thrilled to witness their growing leadership skills throughout the three-year program. A huge shout-out to the remarkable educator, Ramonita Semper, who leads this fantastic program.

Throughout the after-school program, GEMS will make use of Girl Rising resources to explore topics tied to social justice. Let’s hear it for the GEMS and all their super powers.

🌍✨ Celebrating World Science Day for Peace and Development! 🌍✨

Tomorrow, we unite to honor the impact of science in shaping our world, improving our quality of life and promoting global harmony. Science is a guiding light on the path to a better future, and it's crucial we recognize the pivotal role played by scientists in expanding our understanding of our planet and maintaining peace.

World Science Day for Peace and Development is also a vital time to deepen our commitment to gender equity in science. Women continue to be underrepresented in scientific fields, limiting our progress towards an equitable, sustainable, and peaceful world.

Promoting girls' and women's participation in science is not only a matter of justice, but also essential to addressing the world's most pressing challenges. Let's break down barriers and challenge gender bias to ensure all aspiring scientists have the opportunity to fulfill their potential.

🌟 Today is World Science Day for Peace and Development - and we are thrilled to share the voice of Girl Rising Student Ambassador and high school student Laura Cubillos Guzman (@laulaucubillos)who is harnessing the power of science to create a more peaceful and sustainable world through her nonprofit @Asofi.

Women in STEM, particularly those in data science and analytics, contribute significantly to solutions that aid in improving justice systems, reducing crime, and promoting peaceful societies. Laura and Asofi focus their work in rural Colombia, where communities have historically experience violence as a result of armed conflict, intolerance and drug trafficking. Through bootcamps, events in girls’ schools, and through their social media and web platforms, they are connecting girls with the resources they need to pursue STEM careers and advocate for education and opportunities.

At Girl Rising we connect young changemakers like Laura to a global student network of young activists and Girl Rising staff to provide them a platform for knowledge exchange, professional development opportunities and mentorship. Learn more about our Student Ambassador program in the link in our bio.
